Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: Which of the following is not a strategy to avoid becoming an aggressive driver?
questions.answerA: Not expecting delays on a drive
questions.answerB: Maintaining a reasonable following distance
questions.answerC: Keeping your hands on the wheel
questions.explanation: Strategies to avoid becoming an aggressive driver include having realistic expectations about your travel time and the possibility of delays; driving an appropriate speed and keeping a reasonable following distance; avoiding gesturing at other drivers; and keeping your hands on the wheel.

questions.question: When transporting a load, you should inspect the cargo:
questions.answerB: At the end of each day.
questions.answerC: Every time you take a break.
questions.explanation: Cargo and its securement must be inspected every time you take a break during a trip. Be sure to inspect the cargo at least every 150 miles.

questions.question: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a placarded vehicle, you should always:
questions.answerB: Stop within five feet of the tracks.
questions.answerC: Change gears while on the tracks.
questions.answerD: Change lanes while on the tracks.
questions.explanation: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a transit bus, school bus, or placarded vehicle, special procedures apply. Before crossing, stop your vehicle within 50 feet of, but not less than 15 feet from, the nearest rail. Activate your four-way flashers while crossing. Do not stop, change gears, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is proceeding across the tracks.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are activated, you should never:
questions.answerB: Open the hood.
questions.answerC: Release air from the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Open the door to the cab.
questions.explanation: Never apply the brake pedal if your spring breaks are activated. Brakes can be damaged if they are subject to both springs and air pressure.

questions.question: Eating while driving:
questions.answerA: Is a good way to maximize time.
questions.answerB: Is encouraged on long trips.
questions.answerC: Creates a distraction for the driver.
questions.answerD: Is mandatory so cargo is not left unsupervised.
questions.explanation: To reduce the chances of driving distracted, you should avoid eating, drinking, or smoking while driving. Anything that diverts attention from the task of driving is a distraction.

questions.question: If there are no warning gates or lights at a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Not worry because the tracks are likely abandoned.
questions.answerB: Park your vehicle and walk up to the tracks to determine if a train is approaching.
questions.answerC: Look down the tracks in both directions to ensure that no trains are approaching.
questions.answerD: Do whatever surrounding vehicles are doing.
questions.explanation: A passive railroad crossing is a crossing that lacks control devices, like gates or warning lights. Before crossing a passive railroad crossing, you should search the tracks for approaching trains coming from either direction.

questions.question: Off-ramps:
questions.answerB: Can be dangerous for trucks.
questions.answerC: Should not be used by trucks.
questions.explanation: On- and off-ramps can be dangerous when driving a truck. Remember that posted speed limits for ramps may be safe for cars but too fast for trucks.

questions.question: How should you brake if your vehicle loses its ABS?
questions.answerB: Pump the brake repeatedly.
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal down as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is in place as an addition to a braking system. It intervenes to prevent brakes from locking up during hard braking. If ABS is not working, the basic braking functions on a vehicle will still remain, so the driver can continue to drive and brake normally.

questions.question: On a leaf spring:
questions.answerB: Leaves can be missing.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's suspension, verify that leaf springs do not have missing or broken leaves. If at least one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing, the vehicle will be put out-of-service until the defect is fixed.

questions.question: When asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass the parking space while backing, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.answerD: Back into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the right of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: If a load is 10 feet long, it should be secured by a minimum of:
questions.answerB: Two tie-downs.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be restrained by at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. However, all cargo should have at least two tie-downs, no matter the size of the cargo.

questions.question: If you are driving so slowly that you could impede other vehicles, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive with your emergency flashers activated.
questions.answerD: Wave an arm out of your window.
questions.explanation: If you must drive slowly, you should use your emergency flashers to warn other drivers. Be sure that the use of emergency flashers is permitted by local laws.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, once air pressure is lost and the spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: You will be unable to move the vehicle.
questions.answerB: A separate air tank can be used to release the spring brakes for a short period of time.
questions.answerC: You can use the spring brakes to continue driving normally.
questions.answerD: The air tanks will automatically refill to a safe air pressure level.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: To change lanes, you should:
questions.answerB: Move slowly and smoothly.
questions.explanation: Always change lanes slowly and smoothly. If you did not see drivers who are already using the lane you wish to occupy, this will give them a chance to get out of your way or honk their horns to alert you. Always signal when changing lanes.

questions.question: Convex mirrors:
questions.answerA: Cannot be used on vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Can replace flat mirrors.
questions.answerC: Can be helpful to see a wider area.
questions.answerD: Are illegal to be used in most states.
questions.explanation: Many large vehicles have curved, convex mirrors. Convex mirrors allow drivers to see a wider area than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they really are.

questions.question: A driver can rely on front wheel braking to work:
questions.answerB: Under all conditions.
questions.answerC: Under all conditions, except for snow.
questions.explanation: Front wheel braking is effective under all road conditions. It is unlikely that you will experience a front wheel skid, even on ice.

questions.question: When you need to change lanes:
questions.answerA: Other vehicles will likely get out of your way.
questions.answerB: You should change lanes slowly and smoothly.
questions.answerC: You should wait to change lanes until you are in an intersection.
questions.explanation: Lane changes should always be executed slowly and smoothly. This will result in safer handling of your vehicle while allowing time for other drivers to react to your movements.

questions.question: A slack adjuster should move no more than ____ from where it is attached to the push rod.
questions.answerB: Five inches
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should check each slack adjuster after parking, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure that they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle before a trip is:
questions.answerB: To maximize gas mileage.
questions.answerC: To wake up before the drive.
questions.explanation: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle before a trip is to ensure the safety of yourself and others on the road. Safety inspections before every trip are required by state and federal laws.

questions.question: What happens when a vehicle hydroplanes?
questions.answerA: The tires lose contact with the road.
questions.answerB: The tires have extra traction.
questions.answerC: The vehicle is easier to control.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning occurs when a vehicle's tires lose contact with the road surface and instead glide along on a film of water above the surface of the road.

questions.question: When the brake pedal is depressed, air brakes work:
questions.answerB: After a short delay.
questions.answerD: Only if the green lever on the control panel is pushed down.
questions.explanation: After the brake pedal is pushed down in a vehicle with air brakes, it takes a half-second or more for air to flow through the lines and make the brakes work. This contrasts with hydraulic brakes used in cars and light and medium trucks, which instantly begin working when the pedal is pushed.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.answerB: Have an emergency plan.
questions.answerD: Travel faster than the speed limit.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should always scan the road for potential hazards. Formulate plans for how to deal with the hazards if they develop into emergencies.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle with air brakes is ____ in a minute.
questions.answerB: 5 psi
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a triple combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 5 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: When making tight maneuvers, it is important for a driver to:
questions.answerA: Open the door for a better look.
questions.answerB: Use their mirrors.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should always be part of your driving routine, you should make a particular point of checking the mirrors when changing lanes, turning, merging, or making tight maneuvers.

questions.question: If you must drive in reverse, using driver's side backing:
questions.answerB: Is discouraged.
questions.answerC: Is only recommended if it is raining.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, it is safest to back toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This way, as the driver, you will have the best possible view of your path of travel.

questions.question: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull over and figure out what's wrong.
questions.explanation: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should stop driving as soon as possible and try to figure out what is wrong. There could be an issue in your vehicle that could lead to engine failure and possibly a fire.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection:
questions.answerA: Should never be completed the same way two times in a row.
questions.answerB: Should always be completed in the same order.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if it is sunny outside.
questions.answerD: Should not be done if the driver thinks the vehicle is in good operating order.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip inspection should be completed in the same way before every drive. Consistency will help you learn all of the proper steps and decrease the likelihood that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: If being shipped on either a flatbed trailer or a trailer without sides, cargo must be:
questions.answerB: Strapped down.
questions.answerC: Loose to allow it to shift when the vehicle turns.
questions.answerD: Heavy enough that it won’t shift.
questions.explanation: If being shipped on a flatbed trailer or on a trailer without sides, cargo must be securely tied down to keep it from shifting or falling off while the vehicle moves.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, drivers must check the securement of the cargo every:
questions.answerB: 150 miles.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: When trying to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: Swerving may be more effective than stopping.
questions.answerC: You may change lanes without looking.
questions.answerD: You should drive on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the most effective response to a hazard. You can usually turn out of the path of a hazard more quickly than you can come to a complete stop. However, swerving is not without its hazards, as it may result in a rollover in a vehicle that is either top-heavy or pulling multiple trailers.

questions.question: Without engine oil:
questions.answerA: A vehicle will get better gas mileage.
questions.answerB: An engine can be destroyed quickly.
questions.explanation: It is essential that a vehicle's engine have adequate oil pressure. An engine can be destroyed rapidly if it is run without oil.

questions.question: Retreaded tires:
questions.answerA: May be used on the front axle of a school bus.
questions.answerB: May be used on the rear axles of a school bus.
questions.answerC: Cannot be used on a school bus.
questions.explanation: Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are not allowed to be used on the front wheels of a bus.

questions.question: When checking tires, which of the following should not cause concern?
questions.answerB: Tread of at least 4/32 of an inch on front tires
questions.answerC: Radial and bias-ply tires used together
questions.explanation: When checking the tires as part of a pre-trip inspection, make sure the tires have sufficient tread. There should be at least 4/32 of an inch of tread in every major groove of the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch of tread depth on the other tires. Tires should not be mismatched in size and radial and bias-ply tires should not be used together.

questions.question: If approaching a vehicle with a distracted driver, you should:
questions.answerB: Maintain a safe distance from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you see a distracted driver, give them plenty of space and maintain a safe following distance.

questions.question: When backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly to get out of the way of other drivers.
questions.answerB: Try not to use your mirrors.
questions.explanation: Backing a large CMV is always dangerous because you will not be able to see everything behind you. If you must back up, use a helper, if possible.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of retarder?
questions.answerB: Engine
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. The four basic types of retarders are exhaust, engine, hydraulic, and electric.

questions.question: What is the number one cause of death and injury in a work zone?
questions.answerB: Slow drivers
questions.explanation: Speeding is the leading cause of death and injury in work zones. Use extra caution when driving near workers in a work zone.

questions.question: If a load is 40 feet long, the minimum number of tie-downs required to secure the load is:
questions.answerB: Three tie-downs.
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down. There should be at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. Regardless of the size of the cargo, at least two tie-downs must be used.

questions.question: Foundation brakes are used:
questions.answerA: Only on the front wheels of a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Only on the rear wheels of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: On each wheel of a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Foundation brakes are used on each wheel of a CMV. The most common type of foundation brake is the s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: What does ABS do?
questions.answerB: Prevent the air compressor from overheating
questions.answerC: Prevent the front brakes from being used on ice
questions.answerD: Prevent the brakes from being used if downshifting would be more effective
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent wheels from locking up during hard applications of the brakes, especially on slippery surfaces.

questions.question: When checking the springs during a vehicle inspection, do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Look for broken coil springs.
questions.answerC: Ensure torsion springs are not damaged.
questions.explanation: When checking the springs as part of the vehicle inspection test, you should look for missing, shifted, cracked, or broken leaf springs, as well as broken or distorted coil springs. If the vehicle is equipped with torsion bars, torque arms, or other types of suspension components, ensure that they are not damaged and are mounted securely.

questions.question: Alcohol evaporators are:
questions.answerB: Used to introduce alcohol into air brake systems.
questions.answerC: Only allowed in the northern parts of the state.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems have alcohol evaporators, which introduce alcohol into the braking system to help prevent the formation of ice.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter air tanks.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from air tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air tanks are equipped with drains that allow water and compressor oil to be removed from the system. If allowed to build up, water and compressor oil can damage an air brake system.

questions.question: When turning quickly to avoid an object in the roadway, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply your brakes as you steer.
questions.answerB: Give yourself extra clearance by turning more than needed to miss the object.
questions.answerC: Turn just enough to miss the object and avoid turning more.
questions.answerD: Steer and accelerate at the same time.
questions.explanation: When turning quickly to avoid an object, turn only as much as is necessary to clear it. Do not apply the brakes while turning.

questions.question: Within 10 minutes of stopping on the side of the road, you must:
questions.answerB: Alert local law enforcement.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, you must place the appropriate emergency warning devices within 10 minutes of stopping.

questions.question: If involved in an accident, which of the following is not recommended?
questions.answerA: Trying to move your vehicle to the side of the road
questions.answerB: Caring for the injured
questions.explanation: When involved in an accident, you should protect the area, notify authorities, care for the injured, collect required information, and report the accident. You can lose your license for leaving the scene of an accident.

questions.question: If a vehicle has a vehicle inspection report from the previous driver:
questions.answerA: The driver should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and rely on the report.
questions.answerB: The driver should take the vehicle to a mechanic.
questions.answerC: The driver should review the report.
questions.answerD: The driver should speak with the previous driver.
questions.explanation: As the first step of a vehicle inspection, you should review any inspection report left by the previous driver.

questions.question: If a vehicle has a vehicle inspection report, the driver:
questions.answerA: Should not look at the report and instead try to find any issues themselves.
questions.answerB: Should take the vehicle to a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and rely only on the report.
questions.explanation: For the first step of a vehicle inspection, you should review the last inspection report on your vehicle, if there is one. The carrier should have repaired any problems noted on the report.

questions.question: Improperly loaded cargo can:
questions.answerB: Hurt or kill the driver during a quick stop.
questions.answerC: Make it easier to stop a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Improperly secured or loaded cargo can be very dangerous. For example, loose cargo could fall in the event of a sudden stop, potentially injuring or even killing the driver.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, you should:
questions.answerA: First turn the steering wheel in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: First turn the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerC: Turn the wheel as sharply as possible.
questions.explanation: When backing a straight truck, you would turn the wheel in the direction you want to go. By contrast, when backing a vehicle with a trailer, you must turn the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want to go. Once your trailer starts to turn, you should turn the steering wheel the other way to follow the trailer.

questions.question: If you must drive in reverse, it is helpful to:
questions.answerA: Drive as fast as possible and get it over with.
questions.answerB: First exit the truck and walk the path to look for obstacles.
questions.answerC: Use only the passenger side mirror.
questions.answerD: Stick your head out the window and look backward.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in reverse, you should first walk around the vehicle to check for hazards in your path of travel. Make frequent use of the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle while backing. Always back up as slowly as possible.

questions.question: If you are driving at a reduced speed in a construction zone when you spot a construction worker near the road, you should:
questions.answerB: Stay at your current speed.
questions.explanation: Always decrease your speed when traveling through a construction area. Slow down even further if there are workers on or near the roadway.

questions.question: If your wheels being to spin when accelerating on a poor traction surface, you should:
questions.answerB: Take your foot off the accelerator.
questions.explanation: If your drive wheels begin to spin while accelerating on a surface with poor traction, you should remove your foot from the accelerator.

questions.question: To change lanes, you should:
questions.answerB: Move slowly and smoothly.
questions.explanation: Always change lanes slowly and smoothly. If you did not see drivers who are already using the lane you wish to occupy, this will give them a chance to get out of your way or honk their horns to alert you. Always signal when changing lanes.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable if found during a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerB: Tread of 3/32 of an inch in the grooves of the front tires
questions.explanation: When checking the tires as part of a pre-trip inspection, make sure the tires have sufficient tread. There should be at least 4/32 of an inch of tread in every major groove of the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch of tread depth on the other tires. Tire sizes should not be mismatched.

questions.question: When leaving a vehicle unattended, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Only set the parking brake if the vehicle is parked on a slope.
questions.explanation: Always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle unattended.

questions.question: An example of required emergency equipment is:
questions.answerB: A loud horn.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use:
questions.answerB: Dual air brake systems.
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems, in which there are two separate braking systems operated by a single set of controls. Each system operates the brakes on different axles.

questions.question: If a vehicle is power steering-equipped, the hoses should be:
questions.answerB: Securely connected to the battery.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle equipped with power steering, you should inspect the hoses, pumps, and fluid levels. Specifically check the hoses for leaks.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a strategy to avoid becoming an aggressive driver?
questions.answerA: Not expecting delays on a drive
questions.answerB: Maintaining a reasonable following distance
questions.answerC: Keeping your hands on the wheel
questions.explanation: Strategies to avoid becoming an aggressive driver include having realistic expectations about your travel time and the possibility of delays; driving an appropriate speed and keeping a reasonable following distance; avoiding gesturing at other drivers; and keeping your hands on the wheel.

questions.question: If braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add ____ to your vehicle's total stopping distance.
questions.answerB: 15 feet
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to a vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: If other vehicles are having a difficult time getting around your truck on a road with two or more lanes, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: You should stay in the right lane of a multilane road if your vehicle is being slowed down by a heavy load. Allow other vehicles to pass your truck using the left lane.

questions.question: Skids happen when:
questions.answerA: Tires lose their grip on the road.
questions.answerB: There is too much weight in the trailer.
questions.explanation: Skids happen when tires' traction with the road surface decreases. This can be caused by over-braking, over-accelerating, over-steering, and driving too fast.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection:
questions.answerA: Should be done in the same way every time.
questions.answerB: Should be done differently every time.
questions.answerC: Does not always need to include all items of concern.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip vehicle inspection should be done in the same way every time. Consistency will help a driver learn all of the proper steps and decrease the possibility of the driver forgetting to inspect something.

questions.question: When you are about to start down a hill, you should switch into a ____ gear.
questions.answerB: Faster
questions.explanation: Before starting down a hill, be sure to switch into a low gear. Gravity will increase your vehicle's speed as you travel downhill.

questions.question: If turning to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: You should not brake as it could cause the wheels to lock.
questions.answerC: You should turn the wheel very sharply.
questions.answerD: You should hold down the brakes until you are past the hazard.
questions.explanation: If you are turning to avoid a hazard, do not apply the brakes while you are turning. This could easily lock the wheels and create a skid.

questions.question: If unsure if a road is becoming icy, a driver can:
questions.answerB: Open the window and check the front of the mirror for ice.
questions.answerC: Try to look at the road closely.
questions.explanation: If you think the road surface may be becoming icy, you can check for ice on your vehicle by opening the window and feeling the front of the side mirror, mirror support, or antenna. If ice has formed on any of these items, the road is likely becoming icy as well.

questions.question: When other vehicles have trouble seeing you at dawn or dusk, you can increase your visibility by:
questions.answerB: Honking your horn.
questions.explanation: At dawn or dusk, and in snowy or rainy conditions, you should turn on your headlights to make it easier for other road users to see your vehicle.

questions.question: What can happen if the air pressure gets too low in an air brake system?
questions.answerB: The brakes may not work.
questions.answerD: The brakes will be very sensitive.
questions.explanation: Pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can let air out faster than the compressor can replace it, reducing the available air pressure. If the air pressure in an air brake system gets too low, the brakes will no longer work.

questions.question: When nearing a construction worker who is close to the road, you should:
questions.answerB: Decrease your speed.
questions.answerD: Wait until the construction is complete before proceeding.
questions.explanation: In work zones, you should drive at the posted speed limits. Reduce your speed even further when workers are on or near the road.

questions.question: If you see taillights ahead while you are driving in fog:
questions.answerA: The lights may not indicate where the road is as the vehicle may have pulled off the roadway.
questions.answerB: You can assume the vehicle ahead is on the road.
questions.answerC: It may be an optical illusion.
questions.explanation: When driving under foggy conditions, lights cannot be taken as a reliable indication of where the road is. The lights may be coming from a vehicle that has pulled off the road.

questions.question: The air entering air storage tanks may contain:
questions.answerB: Frost.
questions.explanation: The air that enters air storage tanks in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. Because accumulations of these materials can damage the braking system, tanks are equipped with drains to allow their removal.

questions.question: Some air brake systems introduce alcohol into the system to:
questions.answerA: Make the brakes work without squeaking.
questions.answerB: Prevent ice from forming in the brake system.
questions.answerC: Prevent people from breathing the air from the system.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems contain an alcohol evaporator. An evaporator introduces alcohol into the system to help inhibit the formation of ice in cold weather.

questions.question: When making a left turn, you should start the turn:
questions.answerA: Before reaching the center of the intersection.
questions.answerB: No sooner than the center of the intersection.
questions.answerC: After your rear wheels have passed the center of the intersection.
questions.explanation: When making a left turn, you should wait until you reach the center of the intersection before actually beginning to turn. Due to off-tracking, the left side of your vehicle could hit another driver if you begin turning too early.

questions.question: Once cargo is secured:
questions.answerA: You may complete an entire trip without checking it.
questions.answerB: You can drive at least eight hours without checking it.
questions.answerC: You should check it every three hours or 150 miles.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: One way to overcome the challenges of blind spots is to:
questions.answerA: Drive faster than surrounding vehicles so no other drivers can pass you.
questions.answerB: Drive in the left lane, allowing you to only worry about vehicles to your right.
questions.answerC: Make frequent mirror checks and assess the positions of surrounding vehicles.
questions.explanation: You should make frequent mirror checks to monitor the traffic around you. This should help you notice if surrounding vehicles begin to move into your blind spots.

questions.question: A ramp's posted speed limit:
questions.answerB: Is suitable for some vehicles, but may be too fast for a large CMV.
questions.answerC: Is just a suggestion and may be exceeded.
questions.explanation: Posted speed limits on exit and entrance ramps often show speeds that are safe to be driven by cars. However, these speed limits may be too fast for large or heavily-loaded vehicles and CMV drivers will likely need to slow down to a speed below the posted limit.

questions.question: Which of the following can help you determine when to upshift?
questions.answerB: Engine speed
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: The service brake system:
questions.answerA: Applies and releases the brakes when you press the brake pedal while driving normally.
questions.answerB: Applies and releases the parking brakes.
questions.answerC: Applies and releases the emergency brake.
questions.answerD: Applies and releases the axle brake.
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system. The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when you use the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: If the brakes pull to one side or the other when used:
questions.answerB: They need to be checked.
questions.answerC: They will be the most effective.
questions.explanation: If the brakes pull to one side or the other when used, it is an indication of brake trouble.

questions.question: Distracted drivers may be:
questions.answerB: Traveling at consistent speeds.
questions.answerC: Preoccupied with using their cell phones.
questions.answerD: Not talking to anyone else in their vehicles.
questions.explanation: You may be able to tell that another driver is distracted if you can see them drifting within a lane or across lane dividers; traveling at inconsistent speeds; being preoccupied with a cell phone, a map, food, or other items; or engaging in conversation with passengers.

questions.question: If air pressure drops to a level between ____, a visual low pressure warning signal should have already activated.
questions.answerB: 80 and 95 psi.
questions.explanation: A visual low pressure warning signal should activate before air pressure drops to a level between 55 and 75 psi. This signal could be a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: When trying to put out an electrical fire, you should:
questions.answerB: Use a B:C extinguisher.
questions.explanation: B:C fire extinguishers are designed to work on electrical fires and burning liquids. Don't pour water on an electrical fire.

questions.question: Exhaust system parts should:
questions.answerB: Rub against tires.
questions.explanation: It is essential that exhaust system parts are not leaking or otherwise broken. A faulty exhaust system can let poisonous fumes into the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver is involved in a crash down the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and yell at them.
questions.answerB: Stop after the crash scene and report the other driver’s behavior to police.
questions.answerC: Block the driver in with your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you observe a crash involving an aggressive driver, you should stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and inform them of the aggressive behavior you witnessed.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in the air brake system releases air:
questions.answerB: The air pressure has become too high.
questions.explanation: An air brake system has a safety relief valve, which releases air from the tanks if the pressure gets too high. If the valve must operate, something in the system is wrong and should be addressed by a mechanic.

questions.question: What should you do if the braking system cannot build up hydraulic pressure?
questions.answerB: Downshift.
questions.answerC: Hold the brake pedal down as far as it will go.
questions.explanation: If your hydraulic braking system will not build up the pressure needed to slow or stop your vehicle, there are a few possible solutions. Try shifting into a lower gear, pumping the brakes, and/or using the emergency brake.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, belts should be:
questions.answerB: Checked for tightness.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check all belts for tightness and excessive wear. You should learn how much "give" is appropriate for each belt.

questions.question: When using a turn signal, you should not:
questions.answerB: Signal continuously.
questions.answerC: Cancel the turn signal after completing the turn.
questions.answerD: Allow the turn signal to stay on long after the turn has been completed.
questions.explanation: Always signal well ahead of a turn or lane change. Signal continuously until you have completed the turn or lane change, then be sure to cancel the signal so you do not confuse other drivers.

questions.question: You should not use the parking brake:
questions.answerA: If your vehicle is stopped on a level surface.
questions.answerB: If your vehicle is stopped on a slight incline.
questions.answerC: If your vehicle's brakes are very hot.
questions.answerD: If your vehicle's other braking systems seem to be working adequately.
questions.explanation: A parking brake should not be used if the vehicle's brakes are very hot from use on a steep downgrade or if the brakes are very wet and temperatures are freezing. Using the parking brake when brakes are hot could cause damage to the brakes, and using the brakes when they are wet in freezing weather may cause the brakes to ice up, rendering the vehicle immobile.

questions.question: Which of the following is not required emergency equipment?
questions.answerB: Flares
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher. Optional equipment includes tire chains, tire changing equipment, a list of emergency phone numbers, and an accident reporting kit/packet.

questions.question: When traction is poor, a driver should accelerate slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is best to always accelerate very slowly.
questions.answerB: So they do not lose control of their vehicle.
questions.answerC: So the driver does not accelerate faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.answerD: To be the last vehicle through an intersection.
questions.explanation: Speeding up too quickly on a road with poor traction could cause a driver to lose control of their vehicle. In conditions that cause poor traction, a driver should accelerate especially smoothly and gradually.

questions.question: When approaching your vehicle as part of your pre-trip inspection, you should look for what as a sign of trouble?
questions.answerA: A puddle of oil under the vehicle
questions.answerB: Inflated tires
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle for an inspection, you should look underneath the vehicle for fresh leaks of oil, coolant, grease, or fuel. Seeing a fresh puddle of any of these fluids could indicate a safety issue with your vehicle.

questions.question: When traveling down a long downgrade, you should brake by:
questions.answerB: Mostly using the brakes and downshifting occasionally.
questions.explanation: On a downgrade, you should use the braking effect of your engine as the principal way of controlling your speed. Save your brakes for additional slowing or stopping that may be required by road or traffic conditions.

questions.question: A convex mirror is sometimes called a ____ mirror.
questions.answerB: Square
questions.explanation: Large vehicles often have curved, convex mirrors, sometimes referred to as "fisheye," "spot," or "bug-eye" mirrors. These mirrors provide a wider view than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they actually are.

questions.question: Cargo inside a trailer:
questions.answerA: Does not need to be secured.
questions.answerB: Should be stacked no taller than three feet high.
questions.answerC: Should be secured to prevent movement in transit.
questions.answerD: Should be loaded with the heaviest items on top of lighter items.
questions.explanation: Cargo must be properly secured to prevent it from moving in transit. Loose cargo can be dangerous to the driver operating the CMV, as well as to other road users.

questions.question: When driving down a steep grade:
questions.answerA: You should ride your brakes all the way down.
questions.answerB: Shift into a higher gear as a way to slow down your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Shift into lower gears as a way to slow down your vehicle.
questions.answerD: The truck should be put in neutral as a way to slow down your vehicle.
questions.explanation: When driving down a steep grade, you should rely primarily on the braking effect of the engine to slow down. To prevent overheating, use your brakes only as a supplement to this slowing technique.

questions.question: Black ice is:
questions.answerA: Usually thick – about half an inch or more of ice.
questions.answerB: Usually thin.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. This makes the road look as if it is merely wet.

questions.question: In bad weather, many drivers:
questions.answerA: Like to drive in front of trucks.
questions.answerB: Like to be on the side of trucks.
questions.answerD: Like to drive without using their lights.
questions.explanation: In bad weather, particularly when visibility is poor, it is common for automobile drivers to follow closely behind trucks. Open up the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you if you are being followed too closely.

questions.question: If a vehicle is carrying hazardous cargo, placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: Only on the front of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: On the front, rear, and sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Only on the driver’s side of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Placards must be placed on the front, the rear, and both sides of a vehicle carrying hazardous cargo. They must be readable from any direction.

questions.question: An empty truck:
questions.answerA: Requires a shorter stopping distance than a full truck.
questions.answerB: Requires a longer stopping distance than a full truck.
questions.answerC: Takes the same distance to stop as a full truck.
questions.explanation: Empty trucks require longer stopping distances than full trucks because they have less traction available.

questions.question: When checking the power steering fluid during a vehicle inspection, you will need to do each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Show where the power steering fluid dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Check for adequate power steering fluid.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the power steering fluid level is above the full mark.
questions.answerD: Ensure that the power steering level is above the refill mark.
questions.explanation: When checking the power steering fluid during the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to indicate where the power steering fluid dipstick is located and show that there is an adequate amount of power steering fluid in the engine compartment. The fluid level must be above the refill mark.

questions.question: A steering wheel should be held:
questions.answerB: With one hand, keeping the other hand free for other tasks.
questions.answerC: With one hand at a time, alternating between hands.
questions.answerD: At the base of the wheel.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should be held firmly with both hands, positioned on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle, you should:
questions.answerB: Apply the air brakes.
questions.explanation: You should always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following is not part of a vehicle’s air brake system?
questions.answerB: Low pressure warning device
questions.explanation: Components of an air brake system include an air compressor, an air compressor governor, air storage tanks, air tank drains, an alcohol evaporator, a safety valve, a brake pedal, foundation brakes, supply pressure gauges, an application pressure gauge, a low air pressure warning signal, a stop light switch, a front brake limiting valve (on some older vehicles), spring brakes, and parking brake controls.

questions.question: How much water needs to be on the surface of a road for a vehicle to hydroplane?
questions.answerB: A good amount, such as a large puddle
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be much water on the road for this to occur.

questions.question: If hydraulic brakes fail, a driver can reduce their speed by:
questions.answerB: Shifting into a lower gear.
questions.answerD: Letting the truck run out of gas.
questions.explanation: If your hydraulic bakes fail, shifting into a lower gear can help slow your vehicle down.

questions.question: Before beginning to drive downhill, you should:
questions.answerA: Take your vehicle out of gear.
questions.answerB: Shift into a lower gear.
questions.explanation: To avoid overusing your brakes, you should always shift into a lower gear before starting down a hill.

questions.question: Once stopped as part of the stop/start maneuver, you should:
questions.answerB: Keep the vehicle in first gear.
questions.explanation: When parking as a part of the stop/start maneuver during the on-road driving skills test, you must apply the parking brake. The gears should be shifted into neutral or park. You must be parked parallel to the curb and should not be blocking any driveways or intersections.

questions.question: When entering a foggy area, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop on the side of the roadway.
questions.answerB: Pass other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Always slow down before entering a foggy area. Use low beam headlights, avoid passing others, and avoid stopping on the side of the roadway. It is safest to completely avoid driving under foggy conditions, if possible.

questions.question: After a trailer starts to turn during backing, you should follow the trailer by:
questions.answerA: Doing nothing. The vehicle will follow naturally.
questions.answerB: Changing the direction of the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Turning the steering wheel farther in its current direction.
questions.explanation: When backing a vehicle with a trailer, you must turn the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want to go. Once your trailer starts to turn, you should turn the steering wheel the other way to follow the trailer.

questions.question: Without engine oil:
questions.answerA: A vehicle will get better gas mileage.
questions.answerB: An engine can be destroyed quickly.
questions.answerC: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) won’t work properly.
questions.explanation: It is critical that an engine have sufficient oil pressure. The engine can be destroyed rapidly if run without oil.

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult to see behind the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Most trucks do not have the ability to move in reverse.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.explanation: Backing a truck is always dangerous because the driver may not be able to see everything behind them. CMV operators should avoid backing whenever possible.

questions.question: During the driving test, when asked to make a lane change:
questions.answerA: You should not be concerned with other motorists.
questions.answerB: You should use your turn signal and change lanes when safe.
questions.answerC: You should make the lane change as quickly as possible, even if that means cutting off another driver.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a lane change during the on-road driving test, you should make the proper traffic checks, use your turn signal, and smoothly change lanes when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Having weight loaded in a way that creates a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Increases the likelihood of a rollover.
questions.answerB: Increases the likelihood that items will fall down.
questions.answerC: Increases the difficulty of unloading the cargo.
questions.explanation: Transporting cargo that is loaded with a high center of gravity increases the risk that the transporting vehicle will tip over. Cargo should be loaded with a safe weight distribution.

questions.question: Most heavy trucks with manual transmissions require ____ to change gears.
questions.answerB: Double clutching
questions.explanation: Most heavy vehicles with manual transmissions require double clutching to shift gears. Learning to effectively change gears by double clutching takes practice.

questions.question: Before beginning downhill, you should:
questions.answerB: Take your vehicle out of gear.
questions.answerD: Rely only on braking to reduce your speed.
questions.explanation: On a steep downgrade, you must use the engine's braking effect as your primary method of speed control. Be sure to decelerate and downshift appropriately before beginning to drive down the hill. Relying too heavily on the brakes may cause them to overheat and fade, becoming less effective.

questions.question: Air pressure should build up in a single air system within:
questions.answerB: 12 minutes.
questions.explanation: In single air systems, air pressure should build from approximately 50 to 90 psi within three minutes.

questions.question: You should always use at least ____ to secure cargo on a flatbed trailer.
questions.answerB: Two tie-downs
questions.explanation: When transporting cargo on a flatbed trailer, you should use at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. Any cargo, no matter how small, should be restrained by a minimum of two tie-downs.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a distracted person that motorists should be worried about?
questions.answerA: A driver talking to a passenger in their vehicle
questions.answerB: A child on the side of the road
questions.answerC: A construction worker on the side of the road
questions.answerD: A person sitting on a bench waiting for a bus
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are not paying attention to the road. Be wary of road workers, drivers who are engaged in conversation with passengers, and children near the road.

questions.question: If a load is 10 feet long, it must be secured by a minimum of ____ tie-downs.
questions.answerB: Three
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down. There should be at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. Regardless of the size of the cargo, at least two tie-downs must be used.

questions.question: Poor weight balance:
questions.answerB: Makes handling a vehicle more difficult.
questions.answerC: Increases a driver’s ability to steer.
questions.answerD: Makes a vehicle easier to stop.
questions.explanation: If the weight of a load is poorly balanced, it can lead to difficult and unsafe handling of a vehicle.

questions.question: Don't spend too much time looking at a single mirror because:
questions.answerB: Looking at mirrors can make you drowsy.
questions.answerC: It can result in you driving a long distance without looking at the road.
questions.answerD: The mirror may not provide an accurate view of the road.
questions.explanation: Check you mirrors frequently while driving, but check them quickly. Staring at one mirror for too long can cause you to drive a long distance without knowing what is ahead.

questions.question: The use of a hand-held mobile device while driving is:
questions.answerB: Acceptable if weather conditions are clear.
questions.explanation: Using a hand-held mobile telephone while operating a CMV is both illegal and dangerous.

questions.question: When conducting a vehicle inspection, you will need to identify all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: The water pump belt.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must check the power steering belt, water pump belt, alternator belt, and air compressor belt for snugness, cracks, or frays. If any of these components are not belt-driven, you must tell the examiner which one(s), and verify that they are operating properly, mounted securely, and not damaged or leaking.

questions.question: Steering wheel play should be no more than:
questions.answerB: 50 degrees.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should have no more than 10 degrees of play. This is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch wheel. If there is more play than this, it may be difficult to steer.

questions.question: To use the stab braking method, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up, release the brakes until the wheels start rolling, then repeat the process.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes about halfway, but allow the wheels to keep rolling.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up and the vehicle stops.
questions.answerD: Apply the emergency brake until the vehicle starts to slow.
questions.explanation: The stab braking method for emergency stops involves fully applying the brakes until they lock up. The brakes are then released until the wheels start rolling, and then the process is repeated.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks require special care because:
questions.answerA: They have low centers of gravity.
questions.answerB: They have high centers of gravity.
questions.explanation: Driving with a dry bulk tank requires special care, both because dry bulk tanks have high centers of gravity and because their loads often shift in transit. Be especially careful when taking turns and curves while operating such a vehicle.

questions.question: During a trip, gauges are:
questions.answerB: The only way a driver can learn of potential trouble with the vehicle.
questions.answerC: A way to learn of potential trouble with the vehicle.
questions.explanation: During a trip, you should regularly check the gauge and instrument panels, mirrors, tires, cargo, and lights for signs of trouble.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerB: Are acceptable to be used on tires in the rear of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable to be used if carrying a light load.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims with welding repairs are never safe to use.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of tire failure?
questions.answerB: Vibration
questions.explanation: If you experience tire failure, you may hear the loud "bang" sound of a blowout or feel a heavy thumping or vibration in your vehicle. If steering begins to feel heavy, or if the rear of your vehicle begins to fishtail, you should stop to check your tires.

questions.question: When completing pre-trip inspections:
questions.answerA: The inspections should be done the same way each time.
questions.answerB: Different items should be checked each time.
questions.answerC: It is acceptable to check items in a different order each time.
questions.answerD: Not every item needs to be inspected each time.
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: Vehicles equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have ____ malfunction lamps to indicate when the ABS is not working.
questions.answerB: Blue
questions.explanation: Vehicles with ABS have yellow malfunction lamps to alert drivers when the braking systems are not working. Be sure you know where the malfunction lamp on your vehicle is before beginning a trip.

questions.question: When asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.answerB: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull forward to the right, then back in a straight line.
questions.answerD: Pull forward to the left, then back in a straight line.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the right. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: When should you slow for a curve?
questions.answerB: While in the curve
questions.explanation: You should always slow to a safe speed before entering a curve. Slowing while within the curve could cause a skid.

questions.question: What can happen if the exhaust system is not working properly?
questions.answerA: Poisonous fumes may enter the cab.
questions.answerB: Fumes may exit the rear of the muffler system.
questions.explanation: Leaks in an exhaust system are extremely dangerous because they may allow toxic fumes into the cab or sleeper berth, endangering drivers and passengers.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.answerB: Black ice
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. This makes the road look as if it is merely wet.

questions.question: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle before a trip is:
questions.answerB: To maximize gas mileage.
questions.answerC: To wake up before the drive.
questions.explanation: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle before a trip is to ensure the safety of yourself and others on the road. Safety inspections before every trip are required by state and federal laws.

questions.question: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop after a short distance to:
questions.answerA: Check the tightness of the lug nuts.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the tire tread depth is good.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the correct tire was changed.
questions.answerD: See if rocks have gotten into the tread.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, you should stop a short while later to re-check the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: A vehicle inspection is required:
questions.answerB: To get fuel.
questions.explanation: Federal and state laws require that CMV drivers inspect their vehicles before every trip.

questions.question: A person driving with an open window in cold weather may be:
questions.answerB: A person who is dressed inappropriately.
questions.answerC: A person who likes fresh air.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they have their windows rolled down in cold weather.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving test, you will be evaluated on your lane usage. Which of the following is an example of poor lane usage?
questions.answerA: Not driving over curbs or sidewalks
questions.answerB: Stopping behind crosswalks
questions.answerC: Driving in the leftmost lane if more than one driving lane is available
questions.answerD: Finishing a right turn in the rightmost lane
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, make sure you do not put your vehicle over curbs, sidewalks, or lane markings. Stop behind stop lines, crosswalks, or stop signs. On multiple-lane roads, complete turns in the proper lane. Always move to or remain in the rightmost lane, unless the lane is blocked.

questions.question: Good drivers consistently look ____ seconds ahead of their vehicles.
questions.answerB: Five to six
questions.explanation: Most good drivers consistently look down the road 12 to 15 seconds ahead of their vehicles. Watching ahead of your vehicle will allow you to react to upcoming hazards before meeting them.

questions.question: Most heavy vehicles require ____ to change gears.
questions.answerB: Double shifting
questions.explanation: Most heavy vehicles with manual transmissions require double clutching to change gears. A driver should release the accelerator, push in the clutch, and shift into neutral at the same time. After releasing the clutch and allowing the vehicle to change to the necessary speed, the driver should push in the clutch, shift gears, then simultaneously release the clutch and accelerate.

questions.question: Bracing is used to:
questions.answerA: Make items stand taller in a trailer.
questions.answerB: Prevent items from moving in a trailer.
questions.answerC: Make it easier to unload items from a trailer.
questions.explanation: Blocking and bracing are used to prevent cargo from shifting in transit. Blocking is used in the front, in the back, and on the sides of a piece of cargo to prevent movement. Bracing prevents movement by reaching from the upper portion of a piece of cargo to the floor and sides of the cargo compartment.

questions.question: When making tight maneuvers, it is important for a driver to:
questions.answerA: Open their door for a better look.
questions.answerB: Use their mirrors.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should always be part of your driving routine, you should make a particular point of checking the mirrors when changing lanes, turning, merging, or making tight maneuvers.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.answerB: Engine oil.
questions.explanation: Factors that can affect stopping distance include your vehicle's speed, its weight, and the traction provided by the road surface.

questions.question: While driving a vehicle, if an unusual noise or feeling occurs, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume it is not a concern and continue driving.
questions.answerB: Hope the vehicle makes it until it is switched to another driver.
questions.answerC: Check out the situation to determine the proper solutions.
questions.explanation: Use your senses during trips to help you identify mechanical issues. If you see, hear, smell, or feel anything that could indicate trouble, you should stop and check it out.

questions.question: A driver can have:
questions.answerA: Two licenses, one for automobiles and one for trucks.
questions.answerB: Only one license.
questions.answerC: A license for each state in which they plan to drive.
questions.answerD: An automobile license from one state and a CDL from another.
questions.explanation: A person cannot have more than one license. States share driver data through a computer database to prevent the issuance of duplicate licenses.

questions.question: If using air tanks with manually operated drains, how often should you drain the tanks?
questions.answerB: Once a week
questions.explanation: To prevent the build up of oil and water in a vehicle's air tanks, manually operated air tank drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should:
questions.answerA: Stop harder than you would in a vehicle not equipped with ABS.
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the ABS kicks in.
questions.answerC: Brake as you would in a vehicle not equipped with ABS.
questions.answerD: Brake with less force than you would in a vehicle not equipped with ABS.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination that is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would if the vehicle was not equipped with ABS.

questions.question: What should a driver do if their vehicle hydroplanes?
questions.answerB: Use the brakes.
questions.answerC: Release the accelerator and push in the clutch.
questions.answerD: Take the vehicle out of gear.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, you should slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch.

questions.question: Compared to talking on a cell phone while driving, texting while driving is:
questions.answerB: Just as safe.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is even more dangerous than speaking on a phone while driving. In addition to being mentally distracting, texting is also physically distracting.

questions.question: What is a drawback of retarders?
questions.answerA: They may not be permitted everywhere.
questions.answerB: They can help to slow a vehicle.
questions.explanation: A retarder is a device that helps to slow a vehicle, reducing the need for a driver to use the brakes. However, these devices can be noisy and are not permitted everywhere.

questions.question: A steering wheel should be:
questions.answerA: Held with one hand while the other hand rests.
questions.answerB: Held with both hands to ensure an adequate grip.
questions.answerC: Released if the vehicle is approaching a bump.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should be held firmly with each hand on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: If a load is 40 feet long, it must be secured by a minimum of ____ tie-downs.
questions.answerB: Three
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo needs to be tied down. There should be at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. Regardless of the size of the cargo, at least two tie-downs must be used.

questions.question: Poisonous fumes can enter a cab due to:
questions.answerB: Using the wrong type of fuel.
questions.answerC: A lack of oil in the engine.
questions.explanation: A faulty exhaust system is a serious safety hazard. It may allow poisonous fumes to enter the vehicle's cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: An open automobile window in cold weather may indicate that the driver is:
questions.answerB: Inappropriately dressed.
questions.answerC: Using the heat inside their vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' behaviors and identify clues that indicate when person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. A person driving with their window open in cold weather may be impaired.

questions.question: If your license to operate a personal vehicle is revoked or suspended:
questions.answerA: You can get a hardship license to operate a CMV.
questions.answerB: You cannot get a hardship license to operate a CMV.
questions.answerC: Your CDL will not be affected.
questions.explanation: If your license to operate your personal vehicle is revoked, canceled, or suspended, you may not obtain a hardship license to operate a CMV.

questions.question: When approaching a downgrade, how can you reduce the amount of braking that will be needed?
questions.answerB: Switch to a lower gear.
questions.explanation: Always shift to a lower gear before starting down a hill. Doing this will help your vehicle maintain a safe speed without you needing to use the brakes too much.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual air brakes, a leak in one system ____ the second system.
questions.answerB: May not affect
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: Failing to drain air tanks could result in:
questions.answerA: Water accumulations freezing and causing brake failure.
questions.answerB: Squishy brakes.
questions.answerC: Too much air collecting in the tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air tanks must be periodically drained to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. If water is not removed, it could freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

questions.question: When driving, mirrors should be used:
questions.answerA: Only when there may be a problem.
questions.answerB: Infrequently.
questions.explanation: It is essential that you are aware of what is surrounding your vehicle at all times. You should make a habit of regularly checking your mirrors while driving.

questions.question: Interstate carriers must have what information affixed to the commercial motor vehicles in their fleet?
questions.answerB: Width of the truck
questions.explanation: Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations (FMCSR) require carriers to affix the legal name or single trade name to each CMV in their fleet.

questions.question: If a vehicle has air brakes, the air compressor drive belt should be checked before each drive. In what condition should the belt be?
questions.answerB: Tight
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with air brakes that has a belt-driven air compressor, you should check the condition and tightness of the belt. It should be in good condition.

questions.question: Before entering a curve, you should:
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.explanation: Always downshift before entering a curve. Decreasing your speed before entering the curve will allow you to maintain better control over the vehicle throughout the curve.

questions.question: When entering a foggy area, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop on the side of the roadway.
questions.answerB: Pass other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Always slow down before entering a foggy area. Use low beam headlights, avoid passing others, and avoid stopping on the side of the roadway. It is safest to completely avoid driving under foggy conditions, if possible.

questions.question: Hydroplaning happens most often when:
questions.answerA: A vehicle is traveling faster than 60 mph.
questions.answerB: Tire pressure is too low.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is most likely to occur when driving on wet roads with tire pressure that is too low and tire tread that is too worn. If there is enough water on the road, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: To make your vehicle more visible during the day, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your high beam headlights.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights should be used for best visibility, even during the day. Using high beam headlights around other drivers can be dangerous.

questions.question: When driving at highway speeds, you should watch the road about ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: 100 yards
questions.explanation: Stay aware of upcoming obstacles and hazards by consistently watching the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of your vehicle. When traveling at highway speeds, this is equivalent to about a quarter of a mile.

questions.question: To make it as safe as possible to leave a stop, you should park:
questions.answerA: So that you must back up to leave your parking space.
questions.answerB: So that you can pull forward to leave your parking space.
questions.answerC: On the side of a roadway, not in a parking lot.
questions.answerD: By backing into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Backing can be dangerous, so avoid doing it whenever you can. If possible, park in such a way that allows you to pull forward to exit your parking space.

questions.question: An air compressor governor controls:
questions.answerA: When the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: How fast air is pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: The temperature of the air pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: Traction is important in:
questions.answerB: Properly using turn signals.
questions.explanation: You will not be able to brake or steer your vehicle without adequate traction. Ensure that your tires are in proper working condition before beginning a trip.

questions.question: Alcohol usually:
questions.answerB: Impairs depth perception.
questions.explanation: Alcohol impairs a number of basic functions necessary for safe driving, including muscle coordination, reaction time, depth perception, and night vision. Operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol is both illegal and dangerous.

questions.question: If taking the driving test and the route does not include a railroad crossing, you:
questions.answerA: Will not have to do anything related to a crossing.
questions.answerB: May have to explain how you would cross railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Will have to take the test again on a route that does include a railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: If your on-road driving test route does not include a railroad crossing, you may be asked to explain and demonstrate the proper railroad crossing procedures to the examiner at a simulated location.

questions.question: If asked by a law enforcement officer to take a test to determine your blood alcohol concentration (BAC):
questions.answerA: You can refuse to take the test without a penalty.
questions.answerB: You can refuse taking the test but will be required to pay a $50 fine.
questions.answerC: You will lose your CDL if you refuse to take the test.
questions.explanation: Most states have an Implied Consent Law, which means that by driving a vehicle on the state's roads, you have agreed to undergo a drug or alcohol test if a police officer asks you to do so. If you refuse to submit to a test, you will lose your operating privileges. Make sure you are aware of the laws for every state in which you drive.

questions.question: Lights that indicate that anti-lock brakes are not working are:
questions.answerB: Blue.
questions.explanation: Vehicles equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lights to indicate issues in the braking system.

questions.question: A modulating control valve can control the:
questions.answerB: Landing gear.
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: During a trip, gauges are:
questions.answerB: The only way a driver can learn of potential trouble with the vehicle.
questions.answerC: A way to learn of potential trouble with the vehicle.
questions.explanation: During a trip, you should regularly check the gauge and instrument panels, mirrors, tires, cargo, and lights for signs of trouble.

questions.question: During the driving test, when encountering a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle on the tracks if the other vehicle is going too slow.
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle to check for a train.
questions.answerC: Not change gears while your vehicle is on the tracks.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, do not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in a railroad crossing.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle is:
questions.answerB: 8 psi in a minute.
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A triple combination should have a leakage rate no higher than 6 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: A vehicle stopped at a green light may indicate that the driver:
questions.answerB: Is colorblind.
questions.answerC: Does not know the rules of the road.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they stop in inappropriate places, such as at green traffic lights.

questions.question: In very hot weather, tires should be checked regularly because:
questions.answerB: Air pressure may increase with the temperature.
questions.answerC: The tread wears down more quickly than in cooler weather.
questions.explanation: Because air pressure increases with temperature, you should pay special attention to the tire mounting and pressure when traveling in hot weather.

questions.question: Exhaust system parts should:
questions.answerB: Rub against tires.
questions.explanation: It is essential that exhaust system parts are not leaking or otherwise broken. A faulty exhaust system can let poisonous fumes into the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: You should not use your mirrors:
questions.answerB: When making a turn.
questions.answerC: To determine how fast you are traveling.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should be a part of your driving routine, it is particularly important to check your mirrors when changing lanes, turning, merging, and making tight maneuvers.

questions.question: The brake pedal is part of which braking system?
questions.answerB: The parking brake system
questions.explanation: The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when a driver presses the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: What happens when a vehicle hydroplanes?
questions.answerA: The tires lose contact with the road.
questions.answerB: The tires have extra traction.
questions.answerC: The vehicle is easier to control.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning occurs when a vehicle's tires lose contact with the road surface and instead glide along on a film of water above the surface of the road.

questions.question: When backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly to get out of the way of other drivers.
questions.answerB: Try not to use your mirrors.
questions.explanation: Backing a large CMV is always dangerous because you will not be able to see everything behind you. If you must back up, use a helper, if possible.

questions.question: For safety purposes, when should you turn off a retarder?
questions.answerB: When you have a passenger
questions.answerC: When you are carrying a heavy load
