questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. However, using a retarder may cause wheels to skid when they have poor traction. Turn off retarders when traveling under wet, snowy, or icy conditions.

questions.question: Air tank drains should:
questions.answerA: Not be used by the driver.
questions.answerB: Only be used when it is wet outside.
questions.answerC: Be used to drain the tanks completely.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) will:
questions.answerB: Not change the way you apply the brakes.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is in place as an addition to a braking system. It intervenes to prevent brakes from locking up during hard braking. When driving a vehicle with ABS, you should brake in the same way that you would in a vehicle without ABS. It will not necessarily shorten your stopping distance.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerB: Can cause mechanical damage.
questions.explanation: Always speed up smoothly and gradually so that your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle before a trip is:
questions.answerB: To maximize gas mileage.
questions.answerC: To wake up before the drive.
questions.explanation: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle before a trip is to ensure the safety of yourself and others on the road. Safety inspections before every trip are required by state and federal laws.

questions.question: Brakes may get out of adjustment:
questions.answerB: In colder weather.
questions.explanation: Brakes can get out of adjustment quickly, especially if they are used to the point of overheating. Brake adjustment should be checked frequently.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the driver.
questions.answerB: Assume the driver doesn’t see you.
questions.answerD: Wait for the other driver to signal that it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: Whenever you pass another driver, bicyclist, or pedestrian, you should assume as a precaution that they do not see you.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerA: Is a good way to stay awake on long trips.
questions.answerB: Is distracting.
questions.answerD: Should be used to prevent rust from forming.
questions.explanation: Always accelerate smoothly and gradually so that your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: If involved in an accident, which of the following is not recommended?
questions.answerA: Trying to move your vehicle to the side of the road
questions.answerB: Caring for the injured
questions.explanation: When involved in an accident, you should protect the area, notify authorities, care for the injured, collect required information, and report the accident. You can lose your license for leaving the scene of an accident.

questions.question: If carrying a heavy load that is slowing you down, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive in the right lane.
questions.answerD: Keep the vehicle in second gear.
questions.explanation: The right lanes of a roadway are generally intended for vehicles traveling more slowly than surrounding traffic. If being slowed down by a heavy load, you should stay in the right lane.

questions.question: Drivers may use ____ red reflective warning triangles when their vehicle is stopped on the side of the road.
questions.answerB: Three
questions.explanation: If a vehicle carries red reflective triangles, the driver should place three of them as warning devices when the vehicle is parked on the road.

questions.question: Brake fade is a result of:
questions.answerB: Exposure to moisture.
questions.explanation: If brakes are used too much, they will overheat and become less effective. This is referred to as brake fade.

questions.question: If you must drive during periods of high winds, you should:
questions.answerA: Loosen your grip on the steering wheel.
questions.answerB: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: A school bus's long sides are vulnerable to being pushed by winds. If you must drive in windy conditions, you should maintain a strong grip on the steering wheel, try to anticipate wind gusts, and slow down. If necessary, contact your dispatcher for instructions on how to proceed.

questions.question: When students are boarding a school bus, the driver should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Let students know when it is safe to board.
questions.answerB: Count the number of students at the bus stop and ensure that all have boarded.
questions.answerC: Allow student to board in pairs.
questions.answerD: Check all mirrors for students rushing toward the bus.
questions.explanation: Students should always board a school bus in a single-file line.

questions.question: The loading of a school bus:
questions.answerB: Does not need to be supervised.
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year during loading or unloading of school buses than while riding on school buses. Therefore, it is critical that school bus drivers follow appropriate safety procedures during loading and unloading.

questions.question: If a tornado is approaching and the bus is evacuated, where should students go?
questions.answerB: To the closest tree
questions.explanation: If students are evacuated due to a school bus being in the direct path of a sighted tornado, the driver should lead them to shelter in a nearby building. If no such shelter is available, the driver should escort them to a nearby ditch or culvert. They should avoid areas that may be subject to flash flooding and should be far enough from the bus that it would not fall on them if it tipped over.

questions.question: When students are being picked up by a school bus:
questions.answerA: The students should wait at a designated bus stop.
questions.answerB: The driver should pick up students whether or not they are at the designated bus stop.
questions.answerC: The parents should choose where the bus stop will be located.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should load and unload students only at designated stops that have been approved by appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: A blind spot extends at least ____ behind a school bus.
questions.answerB: 50 feet
questions.explanation: A school bus has blind spots immediately below the side flat mirrors, immediately in front of the side flat mirrors, and directly behind the rear bumper. Rear blind spots typically extend 50 to 150 feet behind a bus but can sometimes extend up to 400 feet, depending on the length of the vehicle.

questions.question: When making a stop to pick up students, a driver should ensure all surrounding traffic has stopped before:
questions.answerA: Opening the door and signaling for the students to approach.
questions.answerB: Turning on the alternating red lights.
questions.answerC: Pulling over to the side of the road.
questions.explanation: When stopping to pick up students, a school bus driver should ensure that all surrounding traffic has stopped before opening the door and signaling for the students to approach the bus.

questions.question: If exiting a bus during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must:
questions.answerA: Keep both hands on the handrail.
questions.answerB: Not touch the handrail.
questions.answerC: Maintain a firm grasp on the handrail.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: When conducting a vehicle inspection, you must show each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: That the oil pressure gauge is working.
questions.answerB: That the oil pressure warning light turns off, or that the gauge shows increasing or normal oil pressure.
questions.answerC: That the oil temperature gauge, if equipped, rises to the normal operating range.
questions.answerD: That the oil pressure gauge comes on when brakes are used.
questions.explanation: When checking the oil pressure gauge as part of a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that it is working. The gauge should show increasing or normal oil pressure, or the oil pressure warning light should turn off. If equipped with one, the oil temperature gauge should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: If exiting a bus, a driver must:
questions.answerA: Never make contact with the handrail.
questions.answerB: Maintain contact with the handrail.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.

questions.question: Properly adjusted outside mirrors should allow a bus operator to see how far behind their bus?
questions.answerB: Two bus lengths
questions.explanation: The left and right side flat mirrors on the outside of a school bus should be adjusted so that the driver can see 200 feet (or four bus lengths) behind the bus.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection and looking into the fifth wheel gap, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure there is a gap between the kingpin and the locking jaws.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.
questions.answerC: Make sure the locking jaws are loose.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a tractor/trailer coupling, look into the fifth wheel gap and make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.

questions.question: When completing an offset back/left parking maneuver, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerB: Drive straight back, then pull forward to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull straight forward, then drive straight back.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the left. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: When completing a driver's side parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull forward directly into the parking space.
questions.answerB: Back up past the parking space, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the left of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: If you are taking the driving test and the route does not include a railroad crossing, you:
questions.answerA: Will not have to do anything related to a crossing.
questions.answerB: May have to explain how you would cross railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Will have to take a different route.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, if your route does not include a railroad crossing, the examiner may ask you to explain and demonstrate the necessary procedures at a simulated location.

questions.question: When asked to make a turn while taking your driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signal, but only if other cars are present.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only in the direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: When conducting a vehicle inspection, you will need to identify all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: The water pump belt.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must check the power steering belt, water pump belt, alternator belt, and air compressor belt for snugness, cracks, or frays. If any of these components are not belt-driven, you must tell the examiner which one(s), and verify that they are operating properly, mounted securely, and not damaged or leaking.

questions.question: When inspecting engine compartment belts during the vehicle inspection test:
questions.answerA: The belts should be checked for snugness, each with up to three inches of play.
questions.answerB: The water pump belt does not need to be identified.
questions.answerC: The air compressor belt should be removed.
questions.answerD: The applicant must identify which items are not belt-driven, if any.
questions.explanation: When checking the engine compartment during the vehicle inspection test, you must check the power steering, water pump, alternator, and air compressor belts. In addition to cracks and frays, you should check the belts for snugness, allowing up to three-quarters of an inch of play at the center of each belt. If any of these items are not belt-driven, you must identify them and ensure that their components are operating properly, are not damaged or leaking, and are mounted securely.

questions.question: When entering traffic on an expressway during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerB: Not use signals.
questions.answerC: Abruptly enter a lane of traffic.
questions.answerD: Cut off other drivers if needed.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you may be asked to enter an expressway. Before doing so, you must check traffic, use proper signals, and merge smoothly into the proper lane.

questions.question: During the basic control skills test, you can acquire points by:
questions.answerB: Pulling up one time.
questions.answerC: Exiting the vehicle one time to check your positioning.
questions.explanation: The examiner will score the number of times your vehicle touches or crosses an exercise boundary line. Each encroachment will count as an error, resulting in points against your skills test score.

questions.question: As students exit the bus, the driver should watch students to ensure that:
questions.answerB: They do not get caught on the handrail or door.
questions.answerC: They do not talk while exiting the bus.
questions.explanation: The driver of a school bus should observe students as they enter or exit the bus to ensure that they are not caught in the door or handrails. It is also important to make sure the students have moved a safe distance away from the unloading area after they have exited the bus.

questions.question: When asked to make a turn while taking your driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signal, but only if other cars are present.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only in the direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: When exiting your vehicle, you must maintain ____ with the vehicle at all times.
questions.answerB: Four points of contact
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: Outside mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.answerB: While you are driving.
questions.answerC: After students get on the bus.
questions.explanation: The adjustment of all mirrors on a school bus should always be checked before the bus is driven.

questions.question: The drive shaft should:
questions.answerA: Be bent toward the passenger side.
questions.answerB: Be bent toward the driver’s side.
questions.answerC: Be bent to one side or the other.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you should check that the drive shaft is not bent or cracked.

questions.question: When completing a driver's side parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull forward directly into the parking space.
questions.answerB: Back up past the parking space, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the left of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: If asked to sight-side back your vehicle into an alley, you should first:
questions.answerA: Pull directly into the alley parking space.
questions.answerB: Turn your vehicle to the right to position yourself directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerC: Pull past the alley and stop perpendicular to the outer boundary.
questions.answerD: Pull past the alley and stop parallel to the outer boundary.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: What should properly adjusted outside side flat mirrors on a school bus allow the driver to see?
questions.answerA: The sides of the school bus
questions.answerB: Under the school bus
questions.answerC: The front tires touching the ground
questions.answerD: Vehicles in front of the bus
questions.explanation: When properly adjusted, the outside side flat mirrors on a school bus should allow the driver to see along the sides of the bus; the rear tires touching the ground; and 200 feet behind the bus.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle controls skills test exercise, your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: In the general area that was described by the examiner.
questions.answerB: In the exact final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerC: Within three feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.explanation: You should finish each exercise with your vehicle in the exact position described by the examiner. You can be penalized for failing to complete an exercise exactly in the manner described by the examiner, potentially resulting in failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Show where the dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Show that the engine oil is within safe operating range.
questions.answerC: Show that the oil is below the refill mark.
questions.explanation: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to indicate where the dipstick is located. You will need to show that the oil level is within a safe operating range and above the refill mark.

questions.question: Once stopped as a part of the stop/start maneuver, you should:
questions.answerB: Not use the four-way flashers because it is just a test, not an emergency.
questions.answerC: Leave the vehicle in first gear.
questions.answerD: Park in front of a fire hydrant.
questions.explanation: Once you have stopped as a part of the stop/start maneuver during the on-road driving skills test, you must activate your four-way flashers and shift into neutral or park. You must not block any driveways, intersections, fire hydrants, or signs.

questions.question: If equipped with flashing lights, how far in advance of a school bus stop should the bus's lights be activated?
questions.answerB: At least 100 feet
questions.explanation: If a school bus is equipped with alternating flashing amber warning lights, they should be activated at least 200 feet before a stop, unless state law requires otherwise.

questions.question: Properly adjusted outside convex mirrors should allow the driver to see:
questions.answerA: Where the front of each rear tire touches the ground.
questions.answerB: Where the front of each front tire touches the ground.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, outside convex mirrors should be adjusted to allow the driver to see at least one traffic lane on either side of the bus; the entire side of the bus up to the mirror mounts; and where the front of each rear tire touches the ground.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections should be done:
questions.answerA: Differently each time, emphasizing different items.
questions.answerB: The same way each time so you are less likely to forget something.
questions.answerD: By someone other than the driver.
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: When approaching a school bus stop, the bus driver should:
questions.answerB: Approach the stop with caution.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should always approach bus stops slowly and cautiously.

questions.question: For a basic vehicle control skills test, you are expected to be able to:
questions.answerB: Weave between a line of cones.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: During the basic vehicle control skills test:
questions.answerA: A pull-up always counts against the applicant.
questions.answerB: A pull-up should be completed at least once.
questions.answerC: Stopping without changing direction is not considered a pull-up.
questions.answerD: Excessive pull-ups are acceptable in the opinions of some test administrators.
questions.explanation: During the basic vehicle control skills test, a pull-up will be scored any time an applicant stops and pulls forward to gain a better position. Stopping without changing direction will not. An excessive number of pull-ups will count as errors.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving skills test, you will be evaluated on your gear usage. You should not:
questions.answerB: Select a gear that does not rev the engine.
questions.answerC: Forget to shift through an intersection.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you will be evaluated on your gear usage. Select a gear that does not rev or lug the engine; avoid grinding and clashing gears; and avoid shifting through turns or intersections.

questions.question: When taking the basic vehicle control skills test, failing to exit your vehicle properly during any exercise will result in:
questions.answerB: An extra point against your final score.
questions.answerC: Automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: A school bus stop:
questions.answerA: Can be added by the driver if students are given notice of the change.
questions.answerB: Should be voted on by the students and parents.
questions.answerD: Should be established by the school and not changed.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should never change or add a stop without written approval from the appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: In general, when loading a tank with flammable liquids:
questions.answerB: A ground should be established before opening the filling hole.
questions.answerC: A ground should be broken right before opening the filling hole.
questions.answerD: The filling hole should be locked during loading.
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump. Ground the tank before opening the filling hole and maintain the ground until after closing the filling hole.

questions.question: ____ are used to warn others of hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Flashing lights
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped signs called placards are placed on bulk packages and on the outside of vehicles to warn drivers and others of the presence of hazardous materials. It is the responsibility of the shipper to place the placards, and it is the responsibility of the driver to verify that the correct placards have been placed.

questions.question: On a shipping paper, if the letter “G” appears in Column 1, what else needs to appear?
questions.answerA: The technical name of the hazardous material
questions.answerB: The type of packaging containing the hazardous material
questions.answerD: The date the product was packed
questions.explanation: If the letter “G,” for "Generic," is written in Column 1 of a shipping paper, the technical name of the associated hazardous material must also be listed.

questions.question: When you are seated behind the steering wheel, shipping papers should be:
questions.answerB: In the sleeping compartment.
questions.answerD: Taped to the passenger's side window.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: If a substance is transported in a reportable quantity, which letters must appear on the shipping paper and package?
questions.answerB: LT
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials are being transported in a reportable quantity in one package, the shipper must display the letters "RQ" on the shipping paper and package.

questions.question: As a driver, which of the following is not your job at the scene of an accident?
questions.answerA: Keeping people away from the scene.
questions.answerB: Taking heroic measures to put the fire out.
questions.answerC: Communicating the danger of the hazardous materials to response personnel.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in an accident while carrying hazardous materials, it is your responsibility as the driver to keep people away from the scene; limit the spread of material if you can safely do so; inform emergency response personnel of the dangers posed by the materials; and provide emergency personnel with the shipping papers and emergency response information. Unless you have protective equipment and the necessary training, do not try to fight hazardous materials fires yourself.

questions.question: What does a material’s hazard class reflect?
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material
questions.answerB: How quickly the material must reach its destination
questions.answerD: The country of origin of the materials
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will fall into one of nine hazard classes. The material's hazard class reflects its associated risks.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing while transporting chlorine:
questions.answerA: You must stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerB: You must reduce your speed before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: You may proceed across the tracks without stopping if no warning lights are flashing.
questions.explanation: If transporting any amount of chlorine, a driver must always stop at a railroad crossing 15 to 50 feet from the nearest track, regardless of the presence of a train.

questions.question: ____ is responsible for properly labeling hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: The loader
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials properly. It is a good idea for the driver to ensure the materials are properly labeled.

questions.question: Regulations require hazardous materials employees to be trained and tested how often?
questions.answerB: Once every three years
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials employees must be trained and tested at least once every three years. Drivers must learn the risks associated with hazardous materials and be able to properly respond to security threats.

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the box must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerB: A return address.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Packages that contain liquid containers must have orientation markers. Arrows displayed on the box should be pointing in the correct upright direction.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be:
questions.answerA: Inside a gas station looking through a window.
questions.answerB: In the vehicle, awake or asleep.
questions.explanation: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be awake inside the vehicle or otherwise within 100 feet of the vehicle; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: What is used to warn people about hazardous materials?
questions.answerB: Flashing lights
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped warning signs, called "placards," are placed on the outside of a vehicle carrying hazardous materials to serve as a warning.

questions.question: Regulations relating to hazardous materials are intended to protect all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Those around you.
questions.explanation: Due to the risks involved, government on federal, state, and local levels may impose regulations on the transportation of hazardous materials. These regulations exist to protect the driver, others near the vehicle, and the environment.

questions.question: What does "RQ" stand for?
questions.answerB: Reportable quantity
questions.explanation: When marking hazardous materials in an "HM" column on a shipping paper, the letters "RQ" may be used instead of an "X" if a reportable quantity of the material must be identified.

questions.question: In the event of a cargo fire, opening trailer doors may cause a fire to expand because:
questions.answerA: Oxygen will be allowed into the area.
questions.answerB: The temperature of the trailer will change.
questions.explanation: In the event of a cargo fire, you should not open the trailer doors. Doing this could cause the fire to flare up by giving it access to more oxygen.

questions.question: If transporting explosives, you may leave your vehicle unattended:
questions.answerB: At a truck stop.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: If you discover that your cargo is leaking, you should:
questions.answerA: Touch the leaking material to identify the cargo.
questions.answerB: Use shipping papers and labels to identify the leaking cargo.
questions.answerC: Assume all the cargo is leaking.
questions.explanation: If you discover a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, identify the materials in question by using the shipping papers, labels, or package location. Do not touch the leaking material.

questions.question: The person loading a tank with hazardous materials must be all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Within 10 feet of the tank.
questions.answerC: Aware of the hazards associated with the materials.
questions.explanation: The person in charge of loading or unloading a hazardous materials cargo tank must ensure that a qualified person is always supervising the process. The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: In the Hazardous Materials Table, Column 2 lists:
questions.answerB: Where materials originate.
questions.explanation: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table lists the proper shipping names and descriptions of regulated materials.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.explanation: Brace containers so they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation. All hazardous materials packages must be secured.

questions.question: A shipping paper:
questions.answerA: Is not needed for most shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Is required for all shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can be kept in a digital file.
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to provide proper shipping papers to communicate the risks of the materials.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.answerB: The loader
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials. They must supply any necessary placards.

questions.question: Before loading or unloading flammable liquids, the engine should be:
questions.answerB: Revved up.
questions.explanation: Unless you must run the engine to operate a pump, you should always turn off the engine before loading or unloading flammable liquids.

questions.question: The only way to properly check your tire pressure is by:
questions.answerB: Eyeballing the tires.
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tires to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: How do you label a package if the hazardous materials label will not fit onto the package?
questions.answerA: Place the label on a tag securely attached to the item.
questions.answerB: Attach a QR Code to be scanned.
questions.answerC: Reduce the size of the HazMat label to fit it completely on the item.
questions.explanation: Shippers should place applicable diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on hazardous materials packages. If a label will not fit entirely onto a package, shippers may instead place the label on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: On a shipping paper describing both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials may be identified by being:
questions.answerB: Written in pencil.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper includes information about both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous items must be clearly identified on the paper. They may be entered first, highlighted in a contrasting color, or identified with an "X" placed before the shipping description.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle can only be moved:
questions.answerA: To make room for other vehicles.
questions.answerB: During an emergency.
questions.answerC: If the vehicle will be traveling a distance shorter than 10 miles.
questions.explanation: A vehicle must be properly placarded before it can be driven. A vehicle that does not display the proper placards may not be moved unless doing so is necessary to protect life or property in an emergency.

questions.question: Which agency helps coordinate emergency response to chemical hazards?
questions.answerB: The Federal Containment Organization
questions.answerC: The United Center for Chemical Assistance
questions.explanation: As a resource to police and firefighters, the National Response Center helps coordinate emergency response to chemical hazards.

questions.question: A driver needs a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to transport hazardous materials in:
questions.answerA: A vehicle requiring a Class A license.
questions.answerB: A vehicle requiring a Class B license.
questions.answerC: A vehicle requiring a Class C license.
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to operate a vehicle of any size to transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be in the vehicle?
questions.answerB: Goggles
questions.explanation: A driver transporting chlorine in cargo tanks must have an approved gas mask in the vehicle, as well as an emergency kit for controlling leaks in dome cover plate fittings on the cargo tank.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle may be:
questions.answerB: Either awake or asleep inside the vehicle.
questions.explanation: A person attending a parked placarded vehicle must be either awake inside the vehicle or they must be within 100 feet of it. If not inside the vehicle itself, the person must have a clear view of the vehicle. The person attending may not be inside the sleeper berth.

questions.question: When trying to control a minor truck fire, what should you do before opening trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.answerB: Throw water on the doors.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. Leave the doors closed if there is a cargo fire.

questions.question: An explosive material is most likely categorized as a ____ hazard.
questions.answerB: Class 3
questions.explanation: Class 1 hazardous materials are typically items that present certain explosion or fire hazards.

questions.question: Who is responsible for identifying the hazard class of materials being shipped?
questions.answerB: The carrier
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for identifying the product's identification number; proper shipping name; hazard class; packing group; and correct packaging, labels, marking, and placards.

questions.question: If you apply for an original or renewal HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a background check through which agency?
questions.answerB: Federal Bureau of Investigation
questions.explanation: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass a background check conducted by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: Shippers must label hazardous materials. If an item is smaller than its label, how should the item be labeled?
questions.answerA: The item may be tied together with other hazardous materials and labeled with a sheet of paper on the outside of the bundle.
questions.answerB: The label may be attached to a tag that is securely attached to the package.
questions.answerC: The item may be marked with a large orange dot.
questions.answerD: The item may be placed in a box displaying a warning label.
questions.explanation: Shippers must place diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on most packages of hazardous materials. If the label won't fit on the package, it can be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: Identification numbers, shipping names, and hazard classes:
questions.answerA: Should be abbreviated on a shipping paper if a small piece of paper is being used.
questions.answerB: Should be abbreviated on a shipping paper to make them easier to read.
questions.answerC: Should not be abbreviated on a shipping paper.
questions.answerD: Should only be abbreviated on a shipping paper if the abbreviations are easy to understand.
questions.explanation: Identification numbers, shipping names, and hazard classes must never be abbreviated when listed on a shipping paper. The only exception to this is if the abbreviation is specifically authorized in the hazardous materials regulations.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle:
questions.answerB: Can only be moved in an emergency.
questions.answerD: Can be driven if it does not contain radioactive materials.
questions.explanation: A vehicle carrying hazardous materials must be appropriately placarded to be driven. An improperly placarded vehicle may only be driven if necessary to protect life or property in an emergency.

questions.question: How do you label a package if the hazardous materials label will not fit onto the package?
questions.answerA: Place the label on a tag securely attached to the item.
questions.answerB: Attach a QR Code to be scanned.
questions.answerC: Reduce the size of the HazMat label to fit it completely on the item.
questions.explanation: Shippers should place applicable diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on hazardous materials packages. If a label will not fit entirely onto a package, shippers may instead place the label on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: To transport hazardous materials, what does a driver need?
questions.answerB: A CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement
questions.answerC: A CDL with a tank endorsement
questions.answerD: A CDL with a cargo endorsement
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to drive a vehicle of any size that is used for transporting hazardous materials.

questions.question: On a shipping paper, the identification number, shipping name, and hazard class should:
questions.answerA: Be abbreviated if using a small piece of paper.
questions.answerB: Only be abbreviated if the abbreviations are easy to understand.
questions.explanation: On hazardous materials shipping papers, the identification number, shipping name, and hazard class must not be abbreviated, unless specifically authorized in the hazardous materials regulations.

questions.question: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must carry a fire extinguisher with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: In general, when loading a tank with flammable liquids:
questions.answerB: A ground should be established before opening the filling hole.
questions.answerC: A ground should be broken right before opening the filling hole.
questions.answerD: The filling hole should be locked during loading.
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump. Ground the tank before opening the filling hole and maintain the ground until after closing the filling hole.

questions.question: As a driver, which of the following is not your job at the scene of an accident?
questions.answerA: Keeping people away from the scene.
questions.answerB: Taking heroic measures to put the fire out.
questions.answerC: Communicating the danger of the hazardous materials to response personnel.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in an accident while carrying hazardous materials, it is your responsibility as the driver to keep people away from the scene; limit the spread of material if you can safely do so; inform emergency response personnel of the dangers posed by the materials; and provide emergency personnel with the shipping papers and emergency response information. Unless you have protective equipment and the necessary training, do not try to fight hazardous materials fires yourself.

questions.question: Hazardous materials may be transported:
questions.answerA: By any driver with a CDL.
questions.answerB: By a driver with a CDL and hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: In rural areas by any driver.
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to operate a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.answerD: A maximum of four feet tall.
questions.explanation: Containers of hazardous materials must be braced so that they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation.

questions.question: A placard indicating hazardous materials is which shape?
questions.answerB: Triangle
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.answerB: 25 feet
questions.explanation: You should not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded cargo tank used to transport materials that are categorized as Class 3 (flammable liquids) or Division 2.1 (gases). Do not smoke or carry a lit cigar, pipe, or cigarette near a vehicle containing flammable or explosive materials.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.answerB: The loader
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials. They must supply the warning placards.

questions.question: Your engine runs a pump used during the delivery of compressed gas. After delivery, you should turn off the engine ____ unhooking the hoses.
questions.answerB: After
questions.explanation: Unless your engine runs a pump for product transfer, turn it off when loading or unloading a compressed gas tank. If you do use your engine to run a pump, you should turn the engine off after the product transfer but before unhooking the hoses.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.explanation: Brace containers so they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation. All hazardous materials packages must be secured.

questions.question: The identification numbers assigned to chemicals can be found:
questions.answerA: In the DOT Emergency Response Guide.
questions.answerB: In the truck's manual.
questions.answerC: In the Periodic Table of Elements.
questions.explanation: Information about hazardous chemicals is found in the Emergency Response Guide (ERG) provided by U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT). The ERG is indexed by the proper shipping names and identification numbers of substances.

questions.question: A manifest for transporting hazardous waste:
questions.answerB: Must be sent electronically.
questions.answerC: Must be attached to the outside of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If you are transporting hazardous waste, you must carry with you a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest. The manifest must be signed by hand.

questions.question: If corrosive materials leak in a trailer, the trailer should be:
questions.answerB: Cleaned with water.
questions.answerC: Left to air dry without washing.
questions.explanation: Parts of a vehicle that have been exposed to corrosive liquids must be thoroughly washed with water.

questions.question: The only way to properly check tire pressure is by:
questions.answerB: Eyeballing the tire.
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tire with your hand.
questions.answerD: Measuring the height of the tire.
questions.explanation: You should examine your tires at the beginning of every trip and after every stop to ensure that they are properly inflated. The only acceptable way to check tire pressure is to use a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: A shipping paper:
questions.answerA: Is not needed for most shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Is required for all shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can be kept in a digital file.
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to provide proper shipping papers to communicate the risks of the materials.

questions.question: If required, ____ identical placards must be placed on a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Four
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, a vehicle must display four identical placards. A placard should be placed on the front, on the rear, and on both sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be in the vehicle?
questions.answerB: Goggles
questions.explanation: If transporting chlorine in cargo tanks, a driver must have an approved gas mask in their vehicle.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.answerB: The loader
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials. They must supply any necessary placards.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerB: To check the connection between the trailer and tractor.
questions.answerD: To test the lights on the trailer.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of retarder?
questions.answerB: Engine
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. The four basic types of retarders are exhaust, engine, hydraulic, and electric.

questions.question: If a vehicle is found to be over-length during a pre-trip inspection, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Trim the length of the load.
questions.answerB: Ask someone else to drive.
questions.answerC: Ensure flags and lights indicating the oversize load are fastened securely.
questions.explanation: If a pre-trip inspection reveals a load to be oversize, the driver must confirm that all required signs, flags, lamps, and reflectors are safely and properly mounted, and that and all required permits are in their possession.

questions.question: If a driver has stopped on the road and is placing triangles to warn other motorists:
questions.answerA: The triangles should be held between the driver and oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: The triangles should be carried behind the driver's back to prevent them from being seen by other drivers until they are placed.
questions.answerC: The triangles should be held as low as possible.
questions.explanation: For your own safety, when placing reflective warning triangles, you should carry them between your body and the oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Front brake limiting valves were intended to:
questions.answerA: Prevent the front tires from skidding.
questions.answerB: Prevent the front tires from overheating.
questions.answerD: Remove uncertainty when applying the brakes.
questions.explanation: Some older vehicles with air brakes have front brake limiting valves. These valves were intended to reduce the risk of front wheels skidding. However, research has shown that such devices are unnecessary, so they should be left in the "normal" position.

questions.question: On trucks and buses, where are ABS malfunction lamps located?
questions.answerB: On the instrument panel
questions.answerC: On the outside of the vehicle by the passenger’s door
questions.explanation: Tractors, trucks, and buses with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps located on their instrument panels. Trailers have yellow ABS malfunction lamps on their left side, either on the front or rear corner.

questions.question: The "crack-the-whip" effect is caused by:
questions.answerB: Driving below the speed limit.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with trailers are vulnerable to rollover due to the "crack-the-whip" effect, which is caused by rearward amplification. Rearward amplification varies from vehicle to vehicle, so it is important that drivers are aware of the rearward amplification of their specific vehicles.

questions.question: If carrying a heavy load that is slowing you down, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive in the right lane.
questions.answerD: Keep the vehicle in second gear.
questions.explanation: The right lanes of a roadway are generally intended for vehicles traveling more slowly than surrounding traffic. If being slowed down by a heavy load, you should stay in the right lane.

questions.question: As part of a pre-trip inspection, you should look for all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Tires with too much air pressure.
questions.answerB: Tires with too much wear.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is tread depth of at least 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch in grooves on the other tires. Be sure that your tires are not too worn, are not cracked, have proper air pressure, and are all equally sized.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerB: Make eye contact with the driver.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, it is most important to get out of their way. Avoid making eye contact and do not gesture at them. Report them to the appropriate authorities once you can safely do so.

questions.question: A cardboard box on the road:
questions.answerB: Should be avoided by driving off the roadway.
questions.explanation: Any foreign object on the road is potentially dangerous. For example, something seemingly harmless, such as a cardboard box or paper sack, could contain a hard or heavy object that could do serious damage to a vehicle.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, you should:
questions.answerA: First turn the steering wheel in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: First turn the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerC: Turn the wheel as sharply as possible.
questions.explanation: When backing a straight truck, you would turn the wheel in the direction you want to go. By contrast, when backing a vehicle with a trailer, you must turn the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want to go. Once your trailer starts to turn, you should turn the steering wheel the other way to follow the trailer.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve:
questions.answerA: Should always be used for parking.
questions.answerB: Should only be used for parking on a downhill.
questions.answerC: Should never be used for parking.
questions.answerD: Should only be used when transporting cargo.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve should not be used for parking. This could cause all of the air to leak out of the braking system, resulting in the brakes releasing. Instead, use the parking brake.

questions.question: When entering traffic, a large vehicle usually needs:
questions.answerA: Less space than is needed for a car.
questions.answerB: About the same amount of space as is needed for a car.
questions.answerC: More space than is needed for a car.
questions.explanation: A large vehicle requires more space when entering or crossing traffic than a smaller vehicle. This is not only because the vehicle itself is larger, but also because it needs a longer distance to accelerate.

questions.question: Which part of a combination vehicle is the most likely to turn over?
questions.answerB: The last trailer
questions.answerC: All parts are equally as likely to turn over.
questions.explanation: In double and triple combinations, the trailer farthest from the tractor is the most vulnerable to rollover.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.answerB: Number of passengers.
questions.explanation: Factors that can affect stopping distance include your vehicle's speed, its weight, and how slippery the road surface is.

questions.question: When experiencing cold weather, be sure to check your vehicle's alcohol evaporator:
questions.answerB: Every day.
questions.explanation: An alcohol evaporator can help prevent ice from building up in an air brake system. In cold weather, the evaporator should be checked and refilled every day.

questions.question: How should you brake if your vehicle loses its ABS?
questions.answerB: Pump the brake repeatedly.
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal down as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is in place as an addition to a braking system. It intervenes to prevent brakes from locking up during hard braking. If ABS is not working, the basic braking functions on a vehicle will still remain, so the driver can continue to drive and brake normally.

questions.question: When you need to brake, how can you warn drivers behind you?
questions.answerA: Tap on the brakes a couple of times.
questions.answerB: Stick your arm out the window.
questions.explanation: To warn drivers behind you that you are about to slow down, it may be a good idea to first lightly tap your brake pedal a few times to make the brake lights flash.

questions.question: If a driver begins to feel fatigued while driving, they should:
questions.answerB: Drink coffee.
questions.answerD: Drive faster to finish the trip more quickly.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel drowsy while driving, the only safe response is to safely leave the road and get some sleep. Using artificial stimulants can be dangerous because they may cause extreme fatigue when they begin to wear off.

questions.question: Drivers talking to passengers in their vehicle should be viewed as:
questions.answerB: Distracted drivers.
questions.explanation: Drivers who are engaged in conversation with passengers may be distracted from the task of driving. Use extra caution when driving near distracted drivers.

questions.question: Which of the following is a sign that brakes will need repair?
questions.answerA: Brake pads are not covered in grease.
questions.answerB: Brake pads are not covered in oil.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your brakes, you should check for cracked drums; shoes or pads covered in oil, grease, or brake fluid; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: When should mirrors be adjusted?
questions.answerB: While driving
questions.explanation: Mirror adjustment should be checked prior to the start of any trip. If your vehicle has a trailer, the trailer must be straight in order for the mirrors to be checked accurately.

questions.question: Rolling backward when beginning to accelerate is dangerous because:
questions.answerB: The truck is not made to go backwards.
questions.answerC: You may hit a vehicle behind you.
questions.explanation: Be sure that you are able to accelerate without first rolling back. Rolling backwards may cause you to collide with a vehicle or other obstacle behind your truck.

questions.question: When driving a 50-foot truck at 50 mph, your minimum following distance should be:
questions.answerB: Five seconds.
questions.explanation: At speeds below 40 mph, you should allow at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle. When traveling at higher speeds, follow the same formula, then add one additional second to your following distance.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, you should:
questions.answerA: First turn the steering wheel in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: First turn the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerC: Turn the wheel as sharply as possible.
questions.explanation: When backing a straight truck, you would turn the wheel in the direction you want to go. By contrast, when backing a vehicle with a trailer, you must turn the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want to go. Once your trailer starts to turn, you should turn the steering wheel the other way to follow the trailer.

questions.question: On a curve, the posted speed limit:
questions.answerA: Is safe to be driven in any vehicle.
questions.answerB: Can still permit a vehicle to tip over.
questions.answerC: Is understood to be the minimum legal speed limit.
questions.explanation: The posted speed limit on a curve may be safe to be taken by cars, but can still be too fast to be taken by larger vehicles, such as trucks. An operator driving their truck at the posted limit on a curve could cause their vehicle to tip over.

questions.question: If a vehicle is accompanied by a vehicle inspection report:
questions.answerA: The driver should first inspect the vehicle, then compare their notes with the report.
questions.answerB: The driver should first look at the report when completing an inspection.
questions.answerC: The driver should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and should rely only on the report.
questions.explanation: As the first step of a vehicle inspection, a driver should review any inspection report left by the previous driver.

questions.question: What eliminates alcohol from the bloodstream?
questions.answerB: Exercise
questions.explanation: The body processes alcohol at a fixed rate that cannot be sped up through tricks like drinking coffee. The only way to sober up is to give the body the time it needs to remove the alcohol on its own.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, what is the maximum leakage rate that is safe for a double combination vehicle?
questions.answerB: 6 psi in one minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: During an inspection, the release arm should be properly seated and the safety latch or lock should be:
questions.answerB: Removed.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the fifth wheel before a trip, you should ensure that the release arm is properly seated and the safety latch or lock is engaged. All components should be present and in proper working condition.

questions.question: What should you do when confronted with an aggressive driver?
questions.answerB: Try to stay in the other driver’s way.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, the most important thing for you to do is get out of their way. Avoid making eye contact, do not challenge them by increasing your speed, and do not let yourself be provoked by any angry gestures they direct toward you.

questions.question: If a truck is equipped, a trailer brake hand valve can be used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent the truck from rolling back when being started from a stop.
questions.explanation: If a tractor-trailer is so equipped, the trailer brake hand valve can be used to stop the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.

questions.question: A broken exhaust system can:
questions.answerA: Let poisonous fumes into the cab.
questions.answerB: Improve fuel efficiency.
questions.explanation: Defects in an exhaust system are very dangerous because they can cause poisonous fumes to enter the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: When coupling a double or triple, which trailer should be attached last?
questions.answerA: The trailer directly behind the cab
questions.answerB: The middle trailer
questions.explanation: When coupling a double or triple combination, the rearmost trailer should be the final trailer attached.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a vehicle inspection report?
questions.answerA: It tells the motor carrier about problems that may need to be fixed.
questions.answerB: It ensures that the vehicle is inspected regularly.
questions.answerC: It keeps drivers accountable for inspecting their vehicles.
questions.answerD: It provides a plan for the next five trips.
questions.explanation: A vehicle inspection report allows a driver to inform the motor carrier of issues that could affect the safe operation of a vehicle. If required, the driver should fill out a vehicle inspection report after every day of driving. They should make note of any issues that could affect the safety of the vehicle or that could lead to a mechanical breakdown.

questions.question: When backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly to get out of the way of other drivers.
questions.answerB: Try not to use your mirrors.
questions.explanation: Backing a large CMV is always dangerous because you will not be able to see everything behind you. If you must back up, use a helper, if possible.

questions.question: What is a wig wag?
questions.answerB: A tube used to move air from the compressor to the tanks
questions.answerC: A noise made by air brakes when used
questions.answerD: A part within the braking unit that allows air to move freely
questions.explanation: A wig wag is a type of low air pressure warning device in an air brake system. It drops a mechanical arm into the driver's view when the air pressure in the tanks falls below 60 psi.

questions.question: What is the average driver’s reaction time?
questions.answerB: 1/8 of a second
questions.explanation: The average driver has a reaction time between three-quarters of a second and one second. At 55 mph, this corresponds to a distance of 61 feet traveled.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, drivers must check the securement of the cargo every:
questions.answerB: 150 miles.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: When checking your vehicle's lights before driving:
questions.answerA: The vehicle should be running and in gear.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The check can be done from inside the vehicle.
questions.answerD: The check can be done by looking at a reflection from a shiny surface.
questions.explanation: To check your vehicle's lights before a trip, you should set the parking brake, turn off the engine, remove the key from the ignition, and take the key with you. Turn on your low beam headlights and four-way flashers. Get out of the vehicle to make sure the lights are working properly.

questions.question: When starting an engine, oil pressure should come up to a normal level:
questions.answerB: Within five minutes.
questions.explanation: Look at your truck's gauges when starting the engine. The oil pressure in an engine should come up to a normal level within seconds of the vehicle's engine being started.

questions.question: A convex mirror is sometimes called a ____ mirror.
questions.answerB: Square
questions.explanation: Large vehicles often have curved, convex mirrors, sometimes referred to as "fisheye," "spot," or "bug-eye" mirrors. These mirrors provide a wider view than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they actually are.

questions.question: If a vehicle is equipped with power steering, you should inspect:
questions.answerB: The pumps.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with power steering, check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. In particular, you should look for leaks in the hoses.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable?
questions.answerA: Dual tires that do not come into contact with each other
questions.answerB: Tires of mismatched sizes if used only on short trips
questions.answerC: Retreaded tires on the front of a school bus
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle, you should ensure that dual tires do not come into contact with each other or with other parts of the vehicle. Tire sizes should not be mismatched, and tires should not be cut or damaged in any way. Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are not permitted to be used on the front wheels of a bus.

questions.question: A highway curve should be taken:
questions.answerA: At or slightly above the posted speed limit.
questions.answerB: At the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Well below the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: Due to a high center of gravity, tank vehicles are especially prone to tipping over in turns and curves. To counteract this, you should take curves and ramps at speeds that are well below the posted limits.

questions.question: If other vehicles are having a difficult time getting around your truck on a road with two or more lanes, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: You should stay in the right lane of a multilane road if your vehicle is being slowed down by a heavy load. Allow other vehicles to pass your truck using the left lane.

questions.question: Maintaining a cushion of space between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead is:
questions.answerA: Not encouraged, as it slows the flow of traffic.
questions.answerB: Encouraged, as it allows you time to react to unexpected hazards.
questions.answerC: Only encouraged if you are traveling with a passenger.
questions.explanation: For safe driving, it is essential that you maintain cushions of space on all sides of your vehicle. This helps to ensure that you will have time to take appropriate action if a problem arises.

questions.question: A placard indicating hazardous materials is shaped like a:
questions.answerB: Triangle.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are diamond-shaped.

questions.question: If one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing when a vehicle is inspected:
questions.answerA: The vehicle’s driver will be allowed to drive, but only at reduced speeds.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will be put out-of-service until it is fixed.
questions.answerC: The vehicle will be fine to drive since most of the spring is in place.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle's suspension, you should look for broken or missing leaves in the leaf springs. Any defect of this kind is dangerous. If one-fourth or more of the leaves are missing from any leaf spring, the vehicle must be put out-of-service.

questions.question: When a tank that is divided by bulkheads is being loaded with liquid cargo:
questions.answerA: The section closest to the front of the vehicle should be filled the most.
questions.answerB: The section closest to the rear of the vehicle should be filled the most.
questions.answerC: The middle sections should be filled the most.
questions.answerD: One of the middle sections should be left empty.
questions.explanation: When filling a tank that is divided by bulkheads, make sure that you do not place too much weight on the front or rear of the vehicle.

questions.question: A stopped bus:
questions.answerA: Is not a cause for concern.
questions.answerB: Is not a concern if passengers are not unloading.
questions.answerC: Should not be on the roadway.
questions.answerD: Is a concern, whether passengers are visible or not.
questions.explanation: Always drive cautiously around a stopped bus. Passengers may cross in front of or behind it, and the bus may prevent them from seeing your vehicle.

questions.question: When driving a tank vehicle, a highway curve should be taken:
questions.answerA: At or slightly above the posted speed limit.
questions.answerB: At the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Well below the posted speed limit.
questions.answerD: As fast as surrounding traffic is taking it.
questions.explanation: Tank vehicles' high centers of gravity make them vulnerable to rollover. To reduce this risk, they should be driven well below the posted speed limits on curves and ramps.

questions.question: When starting a vehicle, warning lights and buzzers:
questions.answerA: Should not light up or sound.
questions.answerB: Should turn on and shut off quickly.
questions.answerC: Should turn on and remain on.
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, the warning lights and buzzers should turn on, then quickly turn off.

questions.question: When placing a placard:
questions.answerA: It should be at least three inches away from any other markings.
questions.answerB: It could be placed under a ladder if space is an issue.
questions.answerC: It can be affixed to a background of similar color.
questions.explanation: Among other requirements, hazardous materials placards must be placed at least three inches away from any other markings; away from ladders or other attachments or devices; on backgrounds of contrasting color; and upright, with words or numbers level and reading left to right.

questions.question: When traveling down a hill, you can reduce the amount of required braking by:
questions.answerB: Switching into a lower gear.
questions.explanation: Before starting down a hill, decelerate and shift down into a gear that will allow you to control your vehicle without braking too hard. Using too much brake when driving downhill can cause the brakes to overheat, reducing the braking power.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed to get across the tracks as quickly as possible.
questions.answerB: Roll your window down to listen for a train.
questions.answerD: Never try to outdrive an approaching train.
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed as you approach a railroad crossing. Remember that you will not necessarily be able to hear a train, and don't assume that signals will warn you of its approach. Never try to outdrive an approaching train at a railroad crossing.

questions.question: The best way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is by:
questions.answerB: Seeing it in your mirrors.
questions.explanation: The earliest and best way to recognize the beginnings of a trailer skid is by seeing the trailer veer off-course in your mirrors.

questions.question: How do ice cream trucks become hazardous to other drivers?
questions.answerA: Ice cream trucks must be kept cold.
questions.answerB: Children often run toward an ice cream truck without looking for other traffic.
questions.answerC: Ice cream trucks leave trails of water and ice on the roadway.
questions.explanation: Ice cream trucks can create hazardous conditions for other drivers because they attract children. Children often do not notice or pay attention to other vehicles on the roadway when running to or from ice cream trucks.

questions.question: When entering a curve, you should:
questions.answerB: Use the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Take the vehicle out of gear.
questions.explanation: It is important to take turns and curves at a safe speed. You should always downshift before entering a curve.

questions.question: When backing a truck, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use the side mirrors on the driver’s side.
questions.answerB: Use both side mirrors.
questions.answerD: Only use the mirror on the passenger's side.
questions.explanation: To remain aware of hazards behind your vehicle when backing, you should frequently check your mirrors on both sides of the vehicle. Have a helper watch your blind spots whenever possible.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection should include:
questions.answerA: A check of the engine oil level.
questions.answerB: Removing coolant.
questions.explanation: When examining the engine compartment during a pre-trip inspection, you should check the engine oil level, the radiator coolant level, and the condition of the hoses.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking but the driver does not have access to a phone, they should:
questions.answerA: Drive to a phone to alert emergency personnel.
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean-up facility.
questions.explanation: If a cargo of hazardous materials begins to leak, do not move your vehicle any more than safety requires. If you continue to drive, an even larger area will become contaminated. Instead, you should park your vehicle, secure it, stay with the vehicle, and contact the proper emergency personnel. If you do not have access to a phone, you should send someone else to get help.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of bad brake drums or shoes?
questions.answerB: Pads with oil on them
questions.answerD: Shoes that are not covered in brake fluid
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: If you must back up, it is helpful to:
questions.answerA: Drive as fast as possible to complete the maneuver quickly.
questions.answerB: First walk the line of travel to look for obstacles.
questions.answerC: Use only the passenger side mirror.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, you should exit the cab and check your path for obstacles before beginning the maneuver. Drive as slowly as you can, checking your mirrors on both sides.

questions.question: If a vehicle is carrying hazardous cargo, placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: Only on the front of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: On the front, rear, and sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Only on the driver’s side of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Placards must be placed on the front, the rear, and both sides of a vehicle carrying hazardous cargo. They must be readable from any direction.

questions.question: The safety belt should:
questions.answerB: Latch securely.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should verify that the safety belt is securely mounted, adjusts, latches properly, and is not ripped or frayed.

questions.question: When driving a tank vehicle, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Make sudden stops.
questions.explanation: When driving a tank vehicle, be sure to increase your following distance. Be aware that you could be pushed forward by liquid surge when slowing or stopping.

questions.question: What should you do if the braking system cannot build up hydraulic pressure?
questions.answerB: Downshift.
questions.answerC: Hold the brake pedal down as far as it will go.
questions.explanation: If your hydraulic braking system will not build up the pressure needed to slow or stop your vehicle, there are a few possible solutions. Try shifting into a lower gear, pumping the brakes, and/or using the emergency brake.

questions.question: Unless a package is clearly unsafe, what does the driver need to accept a package of hazardous materials?
questions.answerB: A notarized statement
questions.explanation: Unless a package is clearly unsafe or does not comply with the Hazardous Materials Regulations, you may accept the shipper's certification that it was properly packaged.

questions.question: Blocking cargo:
questions.answerB: Should only be done in poor weather.
questions.explanation: Blocking is used to prevent cargo from sliding while in transit.

questions.question: If you must drive in reverse, using driver's side backing:
