questions.answerB: Is discouraged.
questions.answerC: Is only recommended if it is raining.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, it is safest to back toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This way, as the driver, you will have the best possible view of your path of travel.

questions.question: Drivers trapped behind a slow-moving vehicle often:
questions.answerB: Allow the vehicle plenty of space.
questions.answerC: Are happy with the speed of travel.
questions.explanation: It is common for drivers to tailgate slow-moving vehicles that cannot keep up with the speed of surrounding traffic. If you are being tailgated, allow the other driver to pass your vehicle.

questions.question: When refueling a vehicle transporting hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The engine should be left on.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The gas nozzle may be left unattended.
questions.answerD: Someone other than the driver should do it.
questions.explanation: Always turn the engine off before refueling a vehicle carrying hazardous materials. Someone must always be at the nozzle controlling the fuel flow.

questions.question: Before driving a tank, you should not:
questions.answerA: Assume pipes, connections, and hoses are free of leaks.
questions.answerB: Check the tank’s body or shell for dents or leaks.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the valves are in the correct positions.
questions.explanation: Before driving a tank, check the vehicle for any signs of dangerous leaks. Check the tank's shell, pipes, connections, and hoses. Make sure the valves are in the correct positions before you load, unload, or move the vehicle.

questions.question: What should you do if the coolant temperature gauge rises above the highest safe temperature?
questions.answerB: Pull over and find out what the problem is.
questions.explanation: A coolant gauge rising above the highest safe temperature may indicate that there is a problem with the vehicle that could result in engine failure or a fire in the engine. Stop as soon as you safely can and investigate the problem.

questions.question: If you are turning left at an intersection where there are two available turn lanes:
questions.answerA: It is best to use the right lane.
questions.answerB: It doesn’t matter which lane you use.
questions.answerC: It is best to use the left lane.
questions.explanation: You may have to swing right to safely make a left turn. If there are two left turn lanes available at an intersection, you should always begin your turn in the rightmost lane.

questions.question: Which of the following determines your blood alcohol concentration (BAC)?
questions.answerB: How frequently you drink
questions.explanation: The three main factors that determine a person's blood alcohol concentration (BAC) are how much alcohol was consumed; how fast it was consumed; and the person's body weight. The only thing that can lower a person's BAC is waiting for the alcohol to leave their system naturally.

questions.question: Drivers are usually the least alert:
questions.answerB: In the early evening.
questions.explanation: Drivers are usually less alert when driving at night, especially after midnight.

questions.question: When transporting hazardous materials, placards:
questions.answerB: Should be used on all four sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Should be used only by Class A licensed drivers.
questions.explanation: When required, hazardous materials placards must be placed on all four sides of a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.

questions.question: If pulled over on the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Use the taillights to alert other motorists.
questions.answerB: Turn on your four-way flashers.
questions.answerC: Keep your lights off to avoid distracting other drivers.
questions.answerD: Set out items from the cab to warn motorists.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, you should turn on your emergency flashers and place the appropriate warning signals to warn other drivers.

questions.question: Parts of an exhaust system should be:
questions.answerB: Leaking.
questions.explanation: When inspecting an exhaust system, you should verify that parts of the system are not loose, broken, or missing. The system's parts must be properly mounted and should not be rubbing against moving parts of the vehicle.

questions.question: ABS allows you to:
questions.answerB: Brake harder.
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to help prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. With ABS equipped on your vehicle, you should drive and brake in the same manner that you would without it.

questions.question: When passengers have carry-on baggage, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Place the items in front of the rear exit door.
questions.answerB: Leave the items near the front door.
questions.answerC: Secure the items in a manner that permits all exits to be easily accessible.
questions.explanation: Bus passengers should not be allowed to leave baggage in any doorway or aisle. Baggage and freight must be secured in a manner that will prevent damage, allow the driver to move freely and easily, allow riders to exit by any window or door in an emergency, and protect riders from injury if the items fall or shift.

questions.question: When using your mirrors, you should frequently look at your tires to:
questions.answerB: See if the tires are rolling properly.
questions.answerC: See if the tread is sufficient.
questions.answerD: Get a sense of the size of the tire in relation to other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Check your tires regularly when looking in your mirrors. This helps ensure that you will notice a tire fire, if one should happen. Tire fires may occur when a tire is under-inflated, if dual tires are touching, or if the tires are otherwise overheated.

questions.question: Skids happen when:
questions.answerA: Tires lose their grip on the road.
questions.answerB: There is too much weight in the trailer.
questions.explanation: Skids happen when tires' traction with the road surface decreases. This can be caused by over-braking, over-accelerating, over-steering, and driving too fast.

questions.question: Cargo inside a trailer:
questions.answerA: Does not need to be secured.
questions.answerB: Should be stacked no taller than three feet high.
questions.answerC: Should be secured to prevent movement in transit.
questions.answerD: Should be loaded with the heaviest items on top of lighter items.
questions.explanation: Cargo must be properly secured to prevent it from moving in transit. Loose cargo can be dangerous to the driver operating the CMV, as well as to other road users.

questions.question: Most hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: Should be stored near the engine of a bus.
questions.answerB: May be transported on a bus if passengers are informed in advance.
questions.answerC: Can be transported on a bus if the items can be stored near the rear of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Though there are some exceptions to this rule, most hazardous materials are not permitted to be transported by bus. The safety of your passengers is your responsibility.

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult to see behind the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Most trucks do not have the ability to move in reverse.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.explanation: Backing a truck is always dangerous because the driver may not be able to see everything behind them. CMV operators should avoid backing whenever possible.

questions.question: To check the automatic transmission fluid level in some vehicles, the vehicle:
questions.answerB: Should be parked downhill.
questions.answerD: May have to be left running.
questions.explanation: For some vehicles, you may need to leave the engine running to be able to check its automatic transmission fluid level.

questions.question: To avoid a hazard, you:
questions.answerA: Should always come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: May need to swerve your vehicle out of the way.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the best way to avoid a hazard. If there is not enough space for you to stop to avoid coming into contact with the hazard, swerving out of the way may be your safest option.

questions.question: The steering wheel should be:
questions.answerB: Held by one hand to allow for other tasks, such as eating and drinking.
questions.answerC: Held by one hand at a time, alternating between hands.
questions.answerD: Cracked to allow for an improved grip.
questions.explanation: To maintain proper control of your vehicle, the steering wheel should be held firmly with both hands. Your hands should be positioned on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn the steering wheel as hard as possible.
questions.answerB: Not use the brakes.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch. This will help you to regain traction.

questions.question: When going down a steep downhill, your primary source of braking should be:
questions.answerB: Using the brake.
questions.explanation: On a steep downgrade, you must use the engine's braking effect as your primary method of speed control. Be sure to decelerate and downshift appropriately before beginning to drive down the hill.

questions.question: A bus should be refueled:
questions.answerA: In a closed building while passengers are on board.
questions.answerB: In any location while passengers are on board.
questions.answerC: Without passengers on board, unless absolutely necessary.
questions.explanation: A bus should not be refueled while passengers are on board, unless it is absolutely unavoidable. A bus with passengers on board should never be refueled inside an enclosed building.

questions.question: Bridges usually:
questions.answerA: Freeze, but only once the temperature drops significantly below 32 degrees Fahrenheit.
questions.answerB: Freeze after other road surfaces freeze.
questions.answerD: Have heaters to prevent them from freezing.
questions.explanation: Bridges usually freeze before the rest of the road. You should be especially careful when crossing bridges if the temperature is near the freezing point.

questions.question: After a trailer starts to turn during backing, you should follow the trailer by:
questions.answerA: Doing nothing. The vehicle will follow naturally.
questions.answerB: Changing the direction of the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Turning the steering wheel farther in its current direction.
questions.explanation: When backing a vehicle with a trailer, you must turn the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want to go. Once your trailer starts to turn, you should turn the steering wheel the other way to follow the trailer.

questions.question: The standee line:
questions.answerA: Is a line on the floor of a bus that passengers may not cross.
questions.answerB: Is a single-file line of standing passengers.
questions.answerC: Shows the maximum number of people allowed on a bus.
questions.answerD: Shows how tall the passengers on a bus may be.
questions.explanation: While a bus is traveling, passengers may not stand any farther forward than the rear of the driver's seat. To mark this barrier, a bus that is designed to allow passengers to stand must have a two-inch line on the floor (or some other means of showing passengers where they cannot stand). This is known as the standee line.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of distraction?
questions.answerB: Mental
questions.explanation: Distractions that can affect safe driving can be classified as physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as talking with passenger), or both (such as talking on a hand-held phone).

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult for the driver to see behind the trailer.
questions.answerB: There may be extra weight in the front of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.answerD: Trailers are not made to be driven in reverse.
questions.explanation: Backing is always dangerous because it is impossible to see everything that is behind your vehicle. Only drive in reverse if it is absolutely necessary.

questions.question: Roof hatches on buses:
questions.answerB: Must always be closed when driving.
questions.answerC: May be locked in a partially-opened position.
questions.explanation: On a bus, it is acceptable to lock some roof hatches in a partially-opened position to provide fresh air, but this should not be made a regular practice. Remember that opening these hatches will slightly increase a bus's clearance.

questions.question: A thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces is called:
questions.answerB: Black ice.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet. You should be very careful when temperatures are below freezing and the road looks wet.

questions.question: How should you check your hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should not move.
questions.answerB: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly move toward the floor.
questions.answerC: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly rise.
questions.answerD: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should be easy to push to the floor.
questions.explanation: To test hydraulic brakes, you should pump the brake pedal three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal and hold for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak.

questions.question: When a vehicle is started, the coolant temperature should:
questions.answerB: Rise slowly.
questions.explanation: After an engine is started, the coolant temperature should begin a gradual rise toward the normal operating range.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerA: Always comes as a result of physical distraction, not mental distraction.
questions.answerB: Can be elevated by pre-programming radio stations.
questions.answerC: Can be avoided by eating while driving.
questions.answerD: Can be avoided by not engaging in complex conversations while driving.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of distraction, do not engage in complex or emotionally intense conversations while driving. Pre-programming radio stations before your trip and avoiding eating, drinking, or smoking while at the wheel can also help you avoid becoming distracted while driving. Remember that mental distractions that take your attention away from the task of driving can be just as dangerous as physical distractions.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull off the roadway.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, it is advisable to open up the space in front of your vehicle, making it easier for the tailgater to get around you. Speeding up may be counterproductive because the driver may continue to tailgate you at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: If your coolant level is found to be low, you should:
questions.answerB: Add more coolant.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the engine compartment, you should check the oil level, coolant level, and windshield washer fluid level, among other things. In both cold and hot weather, it is important that the engine have enough coolant.

questions.question: Driving at night is usually:
questions.answerA: More difficult than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Simpler than driving during the day.
questions.explanation: There are several reasons why driving at night is more difficult than driving during the day. It is more difficult for drivers to see hazards, the glare of headlights can affect drivers' vision, and there are more fatigued drivers on the road.

questions.question: When making a tight maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use your mirrors, as they can be distracting.
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors, but not too frequently.
questions.explanation: It is important for you to be aware of your surroundings at all times. To do this, regularly check your mirrors. You should make a particular point of checking your mirrors when merging, changing lanes, turning, and performing tight maneuvers.

questions.question: By beginning a left turn before reaching the center of an intersection, you:
questions.answerA: Will likely complete the turn satisfactorily.
questions.answerB: May hit other vehicles with the left side of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Can expect other drivers to move their vehicles to accommodate your turn.
questions.explanation: When planning to turn left at an intersection, make sure you have reached the center of the intersection before beginning the turn. If you turn too soon, off-tracking may cause the left side of your vehicle to hit another vehicle.

questions.question: Hydroplaning:
questions.answerB: Usually happens when vehicles are traveling at speeds above 65 mph.
questions.answerC: Can occur with a minimal amount of water on the roadway.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be a large amount of water on the road for this to occur. Hydroplaning can begin at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: Black ice is:
questions.answerB: Usually thin.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. The surface will look like a wet road. Always be alert to black ice if the road looks wet when the temperature is below freezing.

questions.question: When traveling on a downgrade, a vehicle will:
questions.answerB: Travel at the same rate as on level roadway.
questions.explanation: On a downgrade, the force of gravity will cause a vehicle to speed up. Adjust your speed before approaching a hill to reduce overuse of your brakes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a driver who might be a hazard?
questions.answerA: A driver operating a vehicle without first scraping ice off the windshield
questions.answerB: The operator of a rental truck
questions.answerC: The driver of a station wagon with items covering the back windows
questions.answerD: A person operating a pick-up truck
questions.explanation: Drivers with blocked vision may pose hazards to others on the road. Examples of such drivers include those who haven't scraped ice off of their windshields; those driving vehicles loaded with large items blocking the windows; and those who are driving rental trucks without being used to the limited rear visibility of a truck.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, you should:
questions.answerA: First turn the steering wheel in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: First turn the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerC: Turn the wheel as sharply as possible.
questions.explanation: When backing a straight truck, you would turn the wheel in the direction you want to go. By contrast, when backing a vehicle with a trailer, you must turn the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want to go. Once your trailer starts to turn, you should turn the steering wheel the other way to follow the trailer.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep grade, you switch into a lower gear:
questions.answerB: When you have already started the grade.
questions.answerC: As far down the grade as possible.
questions.explanation: You should shift your vehicle's transmission into a low gear before staring a downhill grade. Be prepared for gravity to increase your vehicle's speed when traveling downhill.

questions.question: Hydroplaning happens most often when:
questions.answerA: A vehicle is traveling faster than 60 mph.
questions.answerB: Tire pressure is too low.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is most likely to occur when driving on wet roads with tire pressure that is too low and tire tread that is too worn. If there is enough water on the road, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: If you’re not sure how to handle a fire, you should:
questions.answerB: Stay inside the vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure of which method is appropriate to use to extinguish a fire, you should wait for firefighters to arrive and let them handle it. This is especially important when dealing with hazardous materials fires.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.answerB: Have an emergency plan.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should continually scan the road ahead to spot potential hazards well in advance. Make emergency plans for how to deal with the hazards in the event that they become dangerous.

questions.question: Cargo inside a trailer:
questions.answerA: Does not need to be secured.
questions.answerB: Should be stacked no taller than three feet high.
questions.answerC: Should be secured to prevent movement in transit.
questions.answerD: Should be loaded with the heaviest items on top of lighter items.
questions.explanation: Cargo must be properly secured to prevent it from moving in transit. Loose cargo can be dangerous to the driver operating the CMV, as well as to other road users.

questions.question: To inspect slack adjusters on S-cam brakes, you need to:
questions.answerA: Park on a hill and test the brakes.
questions.answerB: Put on gloves and push in the slack adjusters.
questions.answerC: Remove the drum and look inside.
questions.answerD: Chock the wheels and disengage the parking brake.
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after parking on level ground, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: Failing to drain the tanks in an air brake system can result in:
questions.answerA: Water freezing and causing brake failure.
questions.answerB: Squishy brakes.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks must be drained to remove accumulated water and compressor oil. Failing to do this can cause damage. For example, water that has built up in the system could freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle unattended:
questions.answerA: The parking brake should be used.
questions.answerB: The parking brake only needs to be used if the vehicle is parked on a slope.
questions.answerC: The parking brake should not be used, as it can damage the tires.
questions.explanation: In general, you should always use the parking brake when parking your vehicle. However, you should not apply the parking brake if your brakes are very hot or if your brakes are wet and temperatures are below freezing.

questions.question: What is brake lag?
questions.answerA: The time required for the brakes to work after the brake pedal is pressed
questions.answerB: The distance between the brake pedal and the floor
questions.answerC: The amount of air pressure used to stop the vehicle
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work.

questions.question: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks have an air pressure level of:
questions.answerB: 100 psi.
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: Having ABS on only one axle:
questions.answerB: Still allows you additional control when braking.
questions.answerC: Slows the vehicle, but cannot stop it.
questions.explanation: If you have an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) equipped on only the tractor, only the trailer, or only one axle, you will still have more control over the vehicle when braking than you would without ABS. You should brake normally.

questions.question: To make a stop in a vehicle using air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Lift the brake pedal toward them.
questions.explanation: To make a normal stop in an air-braked vehicle, push the brake pedal down and control the pressure so that the vehicle comes to a smooth, safe stop.

questions.question: What must be on an air tank in an air-braked vehicle?
questions.answerB: A lock
questions.explanation: All air tanks on air-braked vehicles must have one-way check valves located between the air compressor and the first reservoir. This prevents air from flowing out in the event of a leak.

questions.question: On newer vehicles, how do you put on the parking brake?
questions.answerA: Move a lever to the right.
questions.answerB: Push in the yellow, diamond-shaped knob.
questions.answerC: Pull out the yellow, diamond-shaped knob.
questions.answerD: Pull up on the steering column.
questions.explanation: On newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The knob is pulled out to set the brakes, and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: Is not available for vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Is not helpful in most driving situations.
questions.answerC: Can help you maintain control when braking.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are compatible with air brakes and help a driver maintain control of their vehicle by preventing wheel lockup.

questions.question: An emergency brake must be controlled by:
questions.answerB: Air pressure.
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes. Because air pressure can eventually leak away, emergency and parking brakes should be held on by mechanical force.

questions.question: The emergency brake system uses:
questions.answerA: Only parts of the parking brake system.
questions.answerB: Only parts of the service brake system.
questions.answerC: Parts of both the parking and service brake systems.
questions.answerD: Only parts unique to the emergency brake system.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, there are three different braking systems: a service brake system, a parking brake system, and an emergency brake system. The emergency brake system uses parts of both the parking and service brake systems.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual air brakes, what happens if one system is low on pressure?
questions.answerA: The air from the other system will be used to supplement the system with the low pressure.
questions.answerB: The front or rear brakes may not work properly.
questions.answerD: The low system will use an auxiliary system to fill the tank.
questions.explanation: In a dual air brake system, if one of the air systems gets very low on pressure, either the front or rear brakes will not be operating fully. You should bring your vehicle to a safe stop and have the air system repaired.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, a leak in one system:
questions.answerA: Always means there are leaks in both systems.
questions.answerB: May not affect the other system.
questions.answerC: Is not something to worry about.
questions.answerD: Will also affect the other system.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: What should happen if the air pressure in the air brake system tanks falls below 60 psi?
questions.answerA: A warning light should come on.
questions.answerB: Lights should flash on the outside of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: A message should appear on the control panel.
questions.explanation: On vehicles with air brakes, a low air pressure warning signal will come on if the pressure in the air tanks falls below 60 psi. On large buses, the signal may activate at 80 to 85 psi.

questions.question: An air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: 250 feet
questions.explanation: A vehicle's total stopping distance is made up of perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. With all of these factors included, an air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately 450 feet to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are activated, you should never:
questions.answerB: Open the hood.
questions.answerC: Release air from the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Open the door to the cab.
questions.explanation: Never apply the brake pedal if your spring breaks are activated. Brakes can be damaged if they are subject to both springs and air pressure.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep downgrade:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be used.
questions.answerB: Shift into a lower gear, then use brakes to supplement the braking effect of the engine.
questions.answerC: The vehicle should be continually downshifted in the place of using the brakes.
questions.answerD: The vehicle should be driven on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: On a downgrade, the braking effect of the engine should be your primary method of controlling speed. Shift down to a lower gear before starting down the hill and save the brakes for additional slowing or stopping that may be required by road or traffic conditions.

questions.question: Using an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerB: Shortens brake response time.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps to provide additional control during hard braking, but does not necessarily shorten a vehicle's stopping distance.

questions.question: If the brake pads rub against the brake drums and create too much heat:
questions.answerB: The brakes will become extra sensitive.
questions.answerD: The air compressor will kick on to cool the brakes.
questions.explanation: Brakes heat up with use. If they are overused and become too hot, expansion and chemical changes will make them less effective and eventually cause them to stop working altogether. This is known as "brake fade."

questions.question: When about to drive a vehicle with a dual brake system, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Let the vehicle warm up to ensure the fuel reaches the engine.
questions.answerB: Wait for air pressure to build in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.answerC: Begin driving just after the engine starts.
questions.answerD: Pump the pedal about 20 times to build pressure, then begin driving.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the compressor to build up pressure to at least 100 psi in both systems.

questions.question: What do the two systems of a dual air brake system share?
questions.answerB: An air compressor
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: Air brakes use ____ to function.
questions.answerB: Liquid nitrogen
questions.explanation: The brakes in an air brake system use compressed air to function properly.

questions.question: You should not use the parking brake:
questions.answerA: If your vehicle is stopped on a level surface.
questions.answerB: If your vehicle is stopped on a slight incline.
questions.answerC: If your vehicle's brakes are very hot.
questions.answerD: If your vehicle's other braking systems seem to be working adequately.
questions.explanation: A parking brake should not be used if the vehicle's brakes are very hot from use on a steep downgrade or if the brakes are very wet and temperatures are freezing. Using the parking brake when brakes are hot could cause damage to the brakes, and using the brakes when they are wet in freezing weather may cause the brakes to ice up, rendering the vehicle immobile.

questions.question: To use the stab braking method, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up, release the brakes until the wheels start rolling, then repeat the process.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes about halfway, but allow the wheels to keep rolling.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up and the vehicle stops.
questions.answerD: Apply the emergency brake until the vehicle starts to slow.
questions.explanation: The stab braking method for emergency stops involves fully applying the brakes until they lock up. The brakes are then released until the wheels start rolling, and then the process is repeated.

questions.question: When parking, you should not use the parking brake if:
questions.answerB: The brakes are very cold.
questions.answerC: There is snow on the ground.
questions.explanation: If your brakes are hot after coming down a steep grade, you should not use your parking brake when parking. Let your brakes cool before applying the parking brake or risk damaging the brakes.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle is:
questions.answerB: 8 psi in a minute.
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A triple combination should have a leakage rate no higher than 6 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: To stop in a vehicle that uses air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Engage the brake lever.
questions.explanation: To make a normal stop in a vehicle with air brakes, push the brake pedal down. The harder the pedal is pressed, the more air pressure is released.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal:
questions.answerA: Is not recommended on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Is required on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerC: Is optional on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.explanation: Any vehicle with air brakes must be equipped with a low air pressure warning signal.

questions.question: What does the air compressor governor do?
questions.answerA: Controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: Controls how quickly air leaves the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: Controls the temperature of the air entering the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Controls the temperature of the air leaving the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: When parked on a flat surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Use wheel chocks to prevent your vehicle from moving.
questions.answerB: Not use wheel chocks.
questions.answerC: Use wheel chocks, but only if you have applied the parking brake.
questions.explanation: When parking on a level surface, you should use wheel chocks. If the vehicle is not equipped with spring brakes, this is essential to prevent the trailer from moving.

questions.question: What is removed when an air tank is drained?
questions.answerB: Ammonia
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks are equipped with drains to allow water and compressor oil to be removed. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system.

questions.question: What must be on an air tank in an air-braked vehicle?
questions.answerB: A lock
questions.explanation: All air tanks on air-braked vehicles must have one-way check valves located between the air compressor and the first reservoir. This prevents air from flowing out in the event of a leak.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, air pressure should build from 85 to 100 psi within ____ seconds.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for air pressure to build from 85 to 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems. This should take about 45 seconds.

questions.question: What should happen if the air pressure in the air brake system tanks falls below 60 psi?
questions.answerA: A warning light should come on.
questions.answerB: Lights should flash on the outside of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: A message should appear on the control panel.
questions.explanation: On vehicles with air brakes, a low air pressure warning signal will come on if the pressure in the air tanks falls below 60 psi. On large buses, the signal may activate at 80 to 85 psi.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, once air pressure is lost and the spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: You will be unable to move the vehicle.
questions.answerB: A separate air tank can be used to release the spring brakes for a short period of time.
questions.answerC: You can use the spring brakes to continue driving normally.
questions.answerD: The air tanks will automatically refill to a safe air pressure level.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: The parking brake in a newer vehicle is applied by:
questions.answerA: Moving a lever to the right.
questions.answerB: Pushing a yellow, diamond-shaped knob.
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The driver should pull the knob outward to apply the parking brakes and push the knob inward to release them.

questions.question: If one air system in a dual air brake system is very low on pressure:
questions.answerA: None of the brakes will work at all.
questions.answerB: Either the front or rear brakes will not be operating fully.
questions.answerC: There will be no noticeable affect.
questions.answerD: Lights on the outside of the tractor will flash.
questions.explanation: In a dual air brake system, if one of the air systems gets very low on pressure, either the front or rear brakes will not be operating fully. You should bring your vehicle to a safe stop and have the air system repaired.

questions.question: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks have an air pressure level of:
questions.answerB: 100 psi.
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: When you need to stop in an emergency, you should:
questions.answerA: Lock the wheels and skid to a stop.
questions.answerB: Stop in a way that keeps your vehicle in a straight line.
questions.answerC: Stop in a way that turns your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Expect your vehicle to slow down more quickly than usual.
questions.explanation: If you need to make an emergency stop, you can use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method. It's important to brake in a way that keeps your vehicle traveling in a straight line while still allowing you to turn, if necessary.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, what is the maximum leakage rate that is safe for a double combination vehicle?
questions.answerB: 6 psi in one minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: When too much air pressure is lost.
questions.answerB: When a control on the dashboard is activated.
questions.answerC: When the tires have minimal tread depth.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes come on automatically when air pressure drops to an unsafe psi level. Instead of waiting for the spring brakes to automatically activate, you should safely exit the road as soon as you notice the low pressure warning signal and bring your vehicle to a stop while you are still able to control the brakes.

questions.question: Brake fade is a result of:
questions.answerB: Exposure to moisture.
questions.explanation: If brakes are used too much, they will overheat and become less effective. This is referred to as brake fade.

questions.question: The ____ tells a driver how much pressure is in the air tanks.
questions.answerB: Air compressor governor
questions.explanation: A vehicle that is equipped with air brakes must also be equipped with a supply pressure gauge. This gauge tells the driver how much air pressure is in each of the vehicle's air tanks.

questions.question: What helps prevent wheel lockup when braking?
questions.answerB: Air brakes
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent wheel lockup while brakes are being applied.

questions.question: Alcohol evaporators are:
questions.answerB: Used to add alcohol to braking systems to prevent items from freezing.
questions.answerC: Only allowed on vehicles carrying hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems include an alcohol evaporator. The evaporator introduces alcohol into the braking system to prevent the formation of ice, which can cause damage.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Has a single air brake system, but uses two sets of controls.
questions.answerB: Has one air brake system for each side of the truck.
questions.answerC: Has two brakes for each wheel.
questions.answerD: Has two separate air brake systems, but uses a single set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems that use a single set of brake controls. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles. The other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: A driver can rely on front wheel braking to work:
questions.answerB: Under all conditions.
questions.answerC: Under all conditions, except for snow.
questions.explanation: Front wheel braking is effective under all road conditions. It is unlikely that you will experience a front wheel skid, even on ice.

questions.question: If your tractor is equipped with ABS but your trailer is not, the ABS:
questions.answerB: Will still improve your steering control.
questions.answerD: Will allow others to see when you brake.
questions.explanation: In a tractor-trailer combination, if the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the ABS will still improve the driver's steering control. The driver should keep an eye on the trailer and let up on the brakes if the trailer begins to swing out.

questions.question: Pressing and releasing a brake pedal unnecessarily can:
questions.answerA: Release air faster than it can be replaced.
questions.answerB: Add more air to the braking system.
questions.answerC: Make the brake pedal more sensitive.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can release air from the braking system faster than the compressor can replace it.

questions.question: The service air line is attached to the:
questions.answerB: Supply line.
questions.explanation: The service air line carries air and is controlled by either the foot brake or trailer hand brake. The service air line is attached to relay valves, which allow the trailer brakes to be applied quickly.

questions.question: Before a drive, ensure that air flows to all trailers by:
questions.answerA: Opening the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerB: Closing the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerC: Disconnecting air supply lines and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerD: Rolling each trailer down a hill and testing the brakes.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that air in the air brake system reaches all trailers. Do this by waiting for air pressure to build, then sending air to both the emergency and service lines and opening the shut-off valves on the rear of the last trailer. If air escapes from the shut-off valves in the rear of the combination, the air is being supplied to the entire vehicle.

questions.question: If color-coded, which color is used to identify emergency, or supply, lines?
questions.answerB: Yellow
questions.explanation: Air lines are sometimes color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes when coupling glad hands. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: The tractor protection valve:
questions.answerA: Ensures that oil adequately lubricates the engine.
questions.answerB: Protects the tractor from exceeding a set speed.
questions.answerC: Keeps air in the truck braking system if the trailer develops a leak.
questions.explanation: A tractor protection valve keeps air in a tractor or truck air brake system should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak. The valve will close automatically if the pressure drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: When braking with ABS, you should:
questions.answerA: Push the brake pedal harder than usual.
questions.answerB: Push the brake pedal as you normally would.
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal more lightly than usual.
questions.explanation: When operating a vehicle with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should apply your brakes in the same manner as you would if operating a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: When traveling more slowly than 40 mph, maintain at least ____ of following distance per every 10 feet of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Two seconds
questions.explanation: At speeds below 40 mph, you should allow at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle. Follow the same formula when traveling at faster speeds, then add one additional second to your following distance. Remember that larger vehicles require more space to stop than smaller vehicles.

questions.question: Emergency air lines are often coded with the color:
questions.answerB: Orange.
questions.explanation: In general, the parts of the service air line are coded blue and the parts of the emergency air line are coded red.

questions.question: To help prevent rollovers, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive slowly around turns.
questions.answerC: Keep the load near the back of the trailer.
questions.answerD: Keep the load on one side of the trailer.
questions.explanation: To lower the risk of a rollover, load your cargo as closely to the ground as possible. To further reduce this risk, take curves and corners slowly.

questions.question: Trailers with low underneath clearance may be difficult to drive:
questions.answerB: Over railroad crossings.
questions.explanation: Railroad-highway crossings may be difficult to cross when pulling a trailer with a low underneath clearance. In particular, both low-slung units and single-axle tractors pulling long trailers are especially challenging to drive over raised crossings.

questions.question: A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause:
questions.answerB: The tractor protection valve to close.
questions.answerC: The rear trailer to detach from the combination.
questions.explanation: The tractor protection valve keeps air in the trailer's braking system should the trailer break away or develop a leak. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the tractor protection valve to open and the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: When backing a trailer, you must first turn the steering wheel:
questions.answerA: In the direction you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerB: In the direction opposite of where you want the trailer to go.
questions.explanation: When backing a vehicle without a trailer, a driver must turn the vehicle in the direction that they want to go. However, when backing with a trailer, the driver must begin by turning in the opposite direction. Once the trailer starts to turn, they should turn the wheel in the other direction to follow the trailer.

questions.question: The emergency air line supplies air to the:
questions.answerB: Trailer air tanks.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line (also known as the supply line) has two functions. The first is to supply air to the trailer air tanks, and the second is to control the emergency brakes on combination vehicles.

questions.question: If a load is placed on one side of a trailer, the trailer:
questions.answerA: May lean, and could result in a rollover.
questions.answerB: May add extra support during turns.
questions.explanation: If the weight of a load is placed primarily one side of a trailer, the trailer may lean, increasing the risk of a rollover.

questions.question: What is the tractor protection valve?
questions.answerA: A valve that keeps air in the brake system should a bad leak occur
questions.answerB: A valve that prevents the trailer from being accidentally released
questions.answerC: A valve that prevents the vehicle from going too fast
questions.explanation: A tractor protection valve keeps air in a tractor or truck air brake system should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak. The valve will close automatically if the pressure drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: Combination vehicles:
questions.answerA: Are usually shorter than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are usually lighter than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerC: Require more skill to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerD: Are easier to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles are usually heavier and longer than single commercial vehicles. For these reasons, they usually require more driving skill than single commercial vehicles.

questions.question: Trailers built before 1975 are:
questions.answerB: Not required to have spring brakes.
questions.explanation: Trailers built before 1975 are not required to have spring brakes. When parking a trailer without spring brakes, be sure to use wheel chocks to prevent the trailer from rolling.

questions.question: Keeping cargo centered on a rig can:
questions.answerB: Prevent a rollover.
questions.explanation: A rollover is more likely if cargo is unevenly loaded in a rig. To help prevent a dangerous rollover, it is important to keep a load as centered on the rig as possible.

questions.question: When testing ____, you should apply your vehicle's brakes with the hand control while moving the vehicle forward slowly.
questions.answerB: The emergency braking system
questions.explanation: To test the trailer service brakes, you should first ensure that the braking system has a normal air pressure level, then release the parking brake. You should then move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control. If the trailer service brakes are working properly, you will feel the brakes activate.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when drivers:
questions.answerB: Do not driving fast enough.
questions.explanation: A rollover happens as a result of a driver taking a turn at too high a speed. Be sure to take turns and curves safely and slowly.

questions.question: When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that you:
questions.answerB: Make sure there is a large enough gap for your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Expect other drivers to make room for your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Let other drivers wave you into their lane.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more space on the road than other vehicles. When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that there is a large enough gap in traffic for you to safely do so.

questions.question: Bobtail tractors are ____ to stop than tractors attached to full semitrailers.
questions.answerB: Easier
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to come to a complete stop than a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: When a combination vehicle goes around a corner:
questions.answerA: The vehicle must use at least two lanes.
questions.answerB: The front and rear wheels will move in different paths.
questions.answerC: It is best to allow the rear wheels to drive over the curb.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels follow a different path than the front wheels. This is called off-tracking. This effect is especially pronounced on vehicles with trailers.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerA: Regularly to activate the trailer brakes in all driving conditions.
questions.answerB: Only to test the trailer brakes.
questions.answerC: Only in inclement weather when the trailer may skid.
questions.answerD: Only if the trailer is carrying a load.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve should be used only to test the trailer brakes. It should not be used while driving because it may cause the trailer to skid.

questions.question: Look into the back of the fifth wheel:
questions.answerB: If your vehicle begins to skid.
questions.explanation: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and look into the back of the fifth wheel. Ensure that the fifth wheel jaws are secured around the shank of the kingpin.

questions.question: In a combination rig, it is best to make:
questions.answerB: Sharp turns.
questions.explanation: When driving a combination vehicle, it is important to brake well in advance and look far ahead of your vehicle to avoid the need for sudden stops. Making habits of these actions will help you prevent your trailer from jackknifing.

questions.question: The "crack-the-whip" effect can:
questions.answerB: Be more effective than braking.
questions.explanation: Trailers can overturn as a result of the "crack-the-whip" effect. The last trailer in a combination is the most prone to tip over due to this effect. Drivers should be aware of the rearward amplification of their specific vehicles and drive accordingly.

questions.question: If you are backing and become unsure about your path of travel, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop and get out to look.
questions.answerC: Continue backing, but more slowly than before.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure of your path while you are driving in reverse, you should stop, exit the vehicle, and recheck your path of travel.

questions.question: One way to prevent a rollover is to:
questions.answerA: Move cargo to the left side of the rig.
questions.answerB: Keep cargo centered on the rig.
questions.answerC: Move cargo to the right side of the rig.
questions.answerD: Keep cargo as far from the ground as possible.
questions.explanation: A rollover is more likely if cargo is unevenly loaded in a rig. To help prevent a dangerous rollover, it is important to keep a load as centered on the rig as possible.

questions.question: When coupling, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure to couple the proper glad hands.
questions.answerB: Only couple one set of glad hands.
questions.answerC: It is best to leave one glad hand loose.
questions.explanation: When coupling air brake hoses, you should make sure the proper pairs of gland hands are connected. They are sometimes color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: When the wheels of a trailer lock up:
questions.answerB: The trailer may swing around.
questions.explanation: A trailer may swing out and strike other vehicles if its wheels lock up. This is especially likely with lightly-loaded trailers.

questions.question: The easiest way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is to:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to determine if the trailer has left the lane.
questions.answerC: Release the brake pedal and then push it down again.
questions.answerD: Watch the jackknife warning light on the control panel.
questions.explanation: The easiest way to spot a trailer skid is to use your mirrors. Any time you brake hard, check your mirrors to ensure that your trailer is still in its proper position.

questions.question: When driving a tractor-trailer equipped with ABS, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop harder than you would otherwise.
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the ABS kicks in.
questions.answerD: Brake using less pressure than you would otherwise use.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would in a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: Test the tractor protection valve by:
questions.answerB: Removing the parking brake control knob.
questions.answerC: Releasing air with the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Releasing air with the gas pedal.
questions.explanation: You should test the tractor protection valve by allowing the air supply to properly charge, turning off the engine, then releasing air from the system by pressing the brake pedal several times. The tractor protection valve should move into its emergency position when psi drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: When a vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels:
questions.answerA: Follow the same path as the front wheels.
questions.answerB: Follow a different path than the front wheels.
questions.answerC: Should not be a concern to the driver.
questions.explanation: When any vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels follow a different path than the front wheels. This is called off-tracking. The degree of off-tracking will be greater on long vehicles than on short vehicles.

questions.question: A trolley valve:
questions.answerB: Should only be used to test trailer brakes.
questions.answerC: Should be used when parking uphill.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve (also referred to as the trolley valve or Johnson bar) is a mechanism that works the trailer brakes. It should only be used to test the brakes. Using it while the vehicle is being driven could cause a skid. Never use the trailer hand valve while parking because doing so may release the air pressure  from the braking system, releasing the brakes that are holding the vehicle in place.

questions.question: To find out if a vehicle that was built before 1998 has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can:
questions.answerA: Pump the air brakes to activate the ABS.
questions.answerB: Look into the back of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerC: Check for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.explanation: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: If a load is placed on one side of a trailer, the trailer:
questions.answerA: May lean, and could result in a rollover.
questions.answerB: May add extra support during turns.
questions.explanation: If the weight of a load is placed primarily one side of a trailer, the trailer may lean, increasing the risk of a rollover.

questions.question: The best way to recognize that your trailer has started to skid is by:
questions.answerB: Checking the trailer in your mirrors.
questions.explanation: The easiest way to become aware that your trailer has begun to jackknife is to observe it in your mirrors. Checking your trailer in your mirrors will also allow you to spot any skidding at the earliest possible moment.

questions.question: After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should:
questions.answerB: Chock the wheels.
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should supply air to the trailer.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve:
questions.answerA: Should always be used for parking.
questions.answerB: Should only be used for parking on a downgrade.
questions.answerC: Should never be used for parking.
questions.explanation: Never use the trailer hand valve while parking because doing so may release the air pressure  from the braking system, releasing the brakes that are holding the vehicle in place. Instead, use the parking brake or wheel chocks.
